item.title: Bakked Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded: Tie-Dyed Cookies – Bakkeds Tie-Dyed Cookies may be the worst baked good we have ever tasted, even worse than if the recipe’s ingredients were extracted and consumed raw. While the bakers were shooting for sugar cookie, what they inevitably produced actually tastes like paint-cookie, only less tart. And they created a sandwich, on top of everything! To throw a frosting between two paint cookies – nay, to include four cookies in the package, total – means 2-4 excruciating doses. It was an experience bad enough to make us avoid Bakkeds other products for good. CannaStats: Contains67mg THC per package, but not worth it.

item.title: Mountain High Suckers
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Mountain High Suckers: Patients have remarked that the suckers are actually as strong as advertised. We certainly concur. With more CBD than almost any other edible – and a research team that constantly tests their competitors – the Mountain High team sticks to the basics but have developed a unique, signature style of impeccable taste and generous cannabinoid content. Also inviting is a mouth-watering presentation: the pineapple-coconut actually has toasted coconut shavings sprinkled delicately along the faade, and other fruity flavors sport their dried derivatives. Overwhelmingly, the blueberry sucker is most sought-after, followed by butterscotch, watermelon, strawberry, tangerine, and more.
CannaStats: 11.7mg THC and a STUNNING 17.69mg CBD

item.title: Gaias Garden, Granny Ts, Sweet Palliatives
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Gaia’s Garden
Zonkey Bar – The Zonkey bar does not sell that well. Its a combination of chocolate, almonds, cranberries, and pumpkin seeds, ultimately creating a questionable sweet taste in your mouth, and probably not enough to bring you back.
PB Blaster – The blaster works because its almost all medicated peanut butter. Essentially a fat, clump of Reeses, but better. That said, its difficult to not eat the whole thing in one fell swoop, especially with the little messiness. Then again, if youre not the kind of person who can easily down 2 Reeses cups consecutively–and especially if you cant handle a plain ol heaping spoonful of pure peanut butter alone–this will probably be too much.
Cloud 9 Bar and Balls – A dwarfed version of the larger and long-retired cloud 9 bars, these little guys pack a punch of THC and sugar. Nothing like chocolate, marshmallows, caramel, pretzels and coconut oil to invigorate the senses. Buy this when its on sale, for $3 or $4 bucks max.
Nookie Cookies - Two heart-shaped cookies. Kind of grainy and plain, but with a little hint of cranberry. Perfect for the vegan in your life.
Razzle Dazzle – The worst part of this bar is that it is white chocolate. White Chocolate lovers will love the white chocolate, but then youll have the problem of dosage compared to price. Gaias Gardens bars have almost always been known for their lower potency (Level 4 equals what, precisely?) and its that thick veil that seems to keep people from coming back. While this bar tastes good–dont buy it unless youre a white chocolate lover to start, and one with lower tolerance.
Almondeus, Milk & Dark – The almond glaze in the middle of the chocolate tastes okay, a moderate almond taste with a very moderate THC chocolate. Almondeus werent always Level 4 bars, to our best memory, but since becoming a Level 4, we havent felt any difference.
Harlequin Bar - Cayenne pepper infused chocolate sounds great, especially with a caramel center, but really isnt anything to write home about. The most annoying part of such an expensive bar, is the fact that you dont feel it very much either.
Rainbow Kaos Krunch - If you didnt think Fruity Pebbles could get any richer, encase a brick of the cereal in milk chocolate with coconut oil. Your tongue will hardly be able to handle the circus in your mouth. I didnt always feel the effects of this – so I gave it to another patient, a burly 230-pound guy whose tolerance was even higher than mine. He reported that it took him out for 10 hours, curiously enough. Another example of how edibles hit everyone differently.
CannaFish – Hard Candy fish in variety of flavors. Comes in 2x or 3x strengths – or at least, did – but not a very patient-appreciated candy line. Plays a second string to Dazys and most suckers. 

Granny Ts
Righteous Krispie Bar - This is not the most impressive cereal bar, but does involve a layer of chocolate. Not sure what else to say. Its a Rice Krispie bar with fairly moderate effect and a layer of freakin chocolate. Good luck fitting it in your mouth.
Peanut Brittle - Unlike other medible Peanut Brittle, often golden and loafed and gourmet-weird, Granny T presents the real thing, harkening to most holiday peanut brittles Ive ever seen. Its familiar. The problem is, how used to buying peanut brittle am I?
Lemon Bar - Definitely the hallmark of a Granny T edible, the Lemon bar looks like the exact replica of a Sunday-brunch-in-the-church-basement dessert, complete with the powdered sugar lining the meringue, and a perfectly powdery pastry crust.

OMG Peanut Butter Cookies – This is a no-brainer edible, a staple, a shelf-stuffer and patient-favorite. Thing is, the peanut butter cookie with Hershey kiss is the most important thing on a cookie platter, the first to go. And while Gaias Garden seemed to commit a bakers faux pas by inverting the chocolate kiss, the move hasnt permanently affected sales (although a pointy kiss seems to sell the cookie). In a retail atmosphere where brown does not sell well, this cookie somehow sells 2 or 3 at a time.

Zesty Crackers – These soup crackers dont have any effect whatsoever–unless youre the kind of person to eat a full bag of soup crackers. Assuming most patients will buy actual food before medicine, no one will be starving enough to try medicating in this absurdly wasteful fashion.

Kettle Chips – By far the worst selling item youll ever see on a dispensary shelf, these Kettle chips are over-salted, glycerin-dipped spuds, but at least have an undeniable effect (all that soaking in Canna-grease really pays off). As far as a shelf-life, these things will sit forever and ruin, simply due to their presentation. Theres a reason you dont buy cheese kettle crackers in a clear plastic bag–they look like the kind of thing Bruce Brodie would wipe his hands with to give a Mallrat diarrhea. Seriously, there is nothing appetizing about the sight of these chips, but if youre into couch-crashing with lots of beer on a Saturday afternoon, they may fit right in.

item.title: How Cannapages Judges Edibles
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
The FIVE Ps
The Hallmark of a Staple Edible, to Cannapages.com:
A good edible doesnt require the whole package to be consumed. We typically insist on eating the whole package unless absolutely necessary, regardless. But a staple edible should not have a short shelf life. It should not require refrigeration, stirring, shaking, preparation, etc.
It should not be a food that consumers wont purchase on a normal basis. Goods that fly off the shelf at grocery stores or holiday party platters work the best. Word of mouth should precede the item (regarding its potency), and first glance should sell it.
That given, a staple edible cant be sold at a price that doesnt match the appearance, without proper explanation or hype. Potency must be explicitly portrayed on the label, especially for small objects. Otherwise, the edible should be very, very presentable, as to guise the hand-production (almost guaranteed at this stage in the industry). It should not be broken, leaking in any way, exposed whatsoever to light or air, smudged, too gooey or too dry. Packaging should be as clean-cut as possible; colors work best in the product and on the label; earth-tones always sell slower.
But most of all, a staple edible must be one that can be consumed day in and day out, or at least in rotation with a small handful of other staples. Whereas a person may not mind tossing a few slightly-offbeat culinary bits into their routine for medication purposes, they will not start directing their diet or snacking habits based on an edibles purchase. You cant expect to sell salsa, cornbread, or even ice cream on a regular basis, because a patient doesnt always carry chips with which to dip the salsa, or have a microwave to warm up todays bite of week-old corn bread, or have to access their ice cream in the freezer when theyre sitting in the library or on a bus. Customers who DO routinely buy one certain niche dietary item from their grocer, will probably find its medicated equivalent enticing at the dispensary. But even then, they may prefer the natural, non-canna version and depend on a completely different type of food or drink. Its not an easy thing to predict.
Ultimately, practicality, price, potency, presentation, and finally, palate, all go into an edibles potential to rise the ranks from generic to staple.

item.title: Benjamins Edibles Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Benilla Wafers: The Benilla Wafers make a good staple. Not to mention, a great improvement on an already great cookie, the vanilla wafer. Sandwiched together between two wafers, the green cannacream hits fairly hard and fast. Slight lemony taste to the cream; addictive and worth eating the whole bag. CannaStats: “100 mg THC” per bag (4 cookies at ~ 25mg each)
Ow-Wee-Ohs: Although the edges always seem to crack off, these large chocolate cookie sandwiches with their signature green Benjamin cream, are the decadent improvement on Oreos. Granted most oreo-based edibles simply consist of the original cookie encased in chocolate, but Benjamins wanted to actually reinvent it altogether. Each cookie sports 50 mg apiece, but only two come to a package. Good luck dosing with this one. CannaStats: “100 mg THC” per bag (2 cookies sandwiches)
Bank Rolls: Not necessarily an improvement on the Cheeba Chew potency, but at least with the taste. Of all the alternative versions of the Cheeba Chew, this one is far most requested. The biggest seller is the taste, more of an orange-based spice and cleaner tasting, without the sharp, pungent undertones associated with Cheebas. Toting 100mg, this seems a formidable opponent (especially for the same retail price, typically). The only things missing are the 3- or 5-pack versions (not to mention hybrid, indica, and sativa distinction). CannaStats: “100 Mg” per roll (compare to 70 mg Quad Dose Cheeba Chews)

Gum: Because its sloshing around your mouth capillaries for so long, this little guy gets right on top of you. It also tastes better than most other gums–but theres nothing to prevent it from losing all taste after 10 minutes. The question is: when is it okay to spit out gum that cost 3 bucks? Thankfully, with 50 mg distributed in a fat, large piece, youll have no problem dosing. Not a good method for night time medicating, though. Benjamin’s downfall was coming out with both 25 and 50 mg versions, which often overlap in pricing on the shelves and/or confuse customers and their bud-tenders.

item.title: Simply Pure Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Gourmet of the Gourmet: Peppermint Cups, Peanut Brittle, Coconut Almond Cups, Sesame Brittle and Granola Bars – phew. Simply Pure is certainly a shrugger as far as Edibles go, just like Whole Foods might be, for a hipster strapped for cash. On the one hand, theyre the brainchild of 8 Rivers Master Chef Scott Durrah and Mad Batter’s Lauren Gennett, and distributed by some of the coolest vendors in the industry. On the other hand, you can only sell $15 Peanut Brittle to a select crowd. The same with a granola bar, especially when the Buddha bar selling off the shelves at such a lower price. Granted, their gourmet chocolates really are gourmet, but even the most gourmet chocolates wont sell to people who dont buy them normally. One thing SP does well is presentation –good product packaging and photography . Then again, youll look at the sesame brittle and ask, Im paying $16 bucks for what? Dosaging: Be forewarned that you cant eat simply pure on an empty stomach–and the chocolates (especially the peppermint cups) are so rich that youll probably have to have something salty nearby to get it down. The record for dosing on this one was 3 packages on an empty stomach – to which the reviewer remarked,I dont know if I feel anything, do you?.

CannaStats: 100mg THC Per Package as advertised. Peppermint cups: around 38mg THC. Granola Bars ~36mg THC. Peanut Brittle Bar ~ STUNNING 71.46 mg THC. Sesame Brittle ~ 54.76 mg THC. Coconut Cups ~ 35.5 mg THC.

Industry Hint: Simply Pure has some big, big things planned for later this year – with not only better and more practical items on the menu, but smaller and more affordable versions of their original line.

item.title: Dixie Elixirs Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded: Elixirs: Once dubbed the more expensive, less effective version of Keef, Dixie Elixirs has come a long way from their hand-bottled days. Although some batches have been spotted with gritty residues at the top of bottles, the general consensus nowadays is that Dixie packs twice the punch of a regular Keef for a similar price (regardless what labels say), and is the better bang-for-buck. Their syrups are special-made out of Cali (including an original Sarsaparilla, whatever that tastes like). Their award winning Blueberry soda is winner among patients; orange tastes perhaps the least medicated. Between Peach, mandarin, and pomegranate, you wont likely be disappointed. Don’t drink until after cold.

item.title: Dazys Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Candies: Dazys flower-shaped candies were the first well-branded hard candies on the market, and to a certain degree, they still are. While they still make a rainbow of colorful varieties, including the best sugar-free version we know of, its been a while since they made a disctinction between certain potency levels for their candies. Not that it would make a difference. The candies have gone downhill since their inception, and patients arent asking for them anymore. Not to mention their cumbersome nature; like Willy Wonkas onscreen gobstoppers, you cant have a conversation, barely swallow juices, and pretty much have to bite the thing in half to keep from drooling on yourself. The price is still good – but not sure if these delicious candies still have the same allure they once did. Then again, there are those who swear by them. CannaStats: 100mg Cannabis Extract (CO2/H2O Extraction From 2.4g Strong Marijuana)

Caps:The best cap, hands down. An expensive one. Hits you hard the first time, the highest youve been in a long, long time. Not for the faint of heart, especially if eaten on an empty stomach. Even for those with high tolerances, the first time will hit you hard, starting with a gut-dropping sensation (free-fall, whether youve eaten or not) and grow into a hardcore high with riveting peaks, climaxing somewhere around hour 3-4 and then coming down accordingly. This, unlike so many other hash cap doses is only a pill for big medicators, and even then, only when you have time to be taken of out commission. CannaStats: 170mg Hash Oil (!)

item.title: North Shore MMJ Edibles Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
North Shore Edibles - Just "Ok."

Assorted Cereal Bars – Tried a Fruity Pebbles Bar. It was pretty good. High on CBD. Body buzz. Mild heady high, back of the head. Nearly two inches thick and impossible to fit in my mouth in a regular gulp – but gooey enough in its carrying case to break apart easily. A little shorter on marshmallow than Id prefer, but still good. Fruity Pebbles Bar was much more satisfying than the Capn Crunch equivalent (The Captain Kreeper).

Suckers – The coolest looking suckers in the industry. The impact is pretty good, but certainly if youre going for taste – or want something out of a real candy store, this sucker delivers the Willy Wonka effect.

Cookies – The best presentation, first. Their packaging ensures that you dont have to take home broken cookies. Taste is okay for both Snicker doodle and white macadamian nut. Not something to rival Grandmas cookies, much less your sisters, but these are definitely potent. Youll feel them right away.

Lemon Fuzzys – Not even sure, from a baking stand point, what we were eating, other than a pile of gooey, lemony deliciousness. From the glaze and frosting on top of the lemon meringue, to the very fat and moist crumbles below, this was decadent madness, and impossible to stop eating. Which is good; with a 2-week shelf life, youll have to eat this one fast. Comes powdered in sugar and perfect for sharing. The only thing not selling it is the name.

Buzz Brownies – Gooey on inside, but if older, much harder to eat on outisde. Also: like those companies who failed the hard way when they learned fudge was not a practical item (something too rich to eat in entirety will never sell or be eaten) – the outside chocolate layer of this brownie is almost too rich too the point of being inedible. The sugar should not out-taste the chocolate. From an effects standpoint – this one kicked in fairly quickly, starting behind the eyes, and lasted 3-4 hours. Reports 2g per package, like everything else.

Hash Caps (Cannabis Oil Capsule) – Somewhat potent but nowhere as noticeable as Dazys. However, for the price (wholesale around $3.50 or $4, meaning a retail of $7-8), these caps are slightly cheaper than the THO equivalent from Delta9. Two come per package, 50mg apiece, and contain both All One and Clarinol. For the price, its a no-brainer…however, make sure to eat on an empty stomach.
item.excerpt:encoded: Not even sure, from a baking stand point, what we were eating, other than a pile of gooey, lemony deliciousness. Continue reading →

item.title: Wild Flour MMJ Edibles Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Regular Style Pretzels from Wild Flour

Pretzels (Regular) - Wild Flours regular pretzels were salty, but they just didnt invoke the taste associated with, well, pretzels. They struck me more like baked, salty dough. Its the only real bland product that Wild Flour makes, but…that makes it easier to restrain from eating the whole bag. Pop a couple of pretzels per dose, and dont let your friends find them. Best on an empty stomach.

Chocolate Coconut Pretzels. Heavenly.

Chocolate Covered pretzels – Despite a somewhat starchy taste initially, these are by far one of the best and addictive edibles for the chocolate lover, or any patient with munchies. The package alone screams Eat me!, with a mouthwatering photo of the little morsels, covered in coconut shavings and nut crumbles. Decadent indeed. The palate hits both salty and sweet, beautifully. Available in single pack, or the party pack, a large package guaranteed to be finished off by one person, save the greatest restraint known to hungry stoners worldwide. 90 mg THC reported, and can sit on the shelf for 60 days. Check the date.

Karma Mel – These are delicately baked with Hash oil. Only 90 mg THC, but none of the butane taste currently associated with carmelized candies. Three little pieces come in each little canister, and as a hard-core canna-binger, I downed one candy, waited ten minutes, and felt it coming on just as I downed the second. The third put on a whole new wave of electric-cheeks and watery eyes – but the whole thing didnt last quite as long as hoped. Then again, there are just five simple ingredients in this thing, all natural (including the bubble hash ice extraction), making it a healthy and chemical-free edible.

Find Wild Flour at a Store Near You.
item.excerpt:encoded: Pretzels (Regular) - Wild Flours regular pretzels were salty, but they just didnt invoke the taste associated with, well, pretzels. They struck me more like baked, salty dough. Its the only real bland product that Wild Flour makes, but…that makes … Continue reading →

item.title: Canyon Cultivation DropIt Liquid THC
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
DropIt Liquid THC from Canyon Cultivation

Canyon Cultivation just erupted onto the Denver scene with a new product called “DropIt,” which is liquid THC. A 3ml bottle of the stuff, in a tiny little vial, is a crazy 375 mg THC in total, with 5mg in every drop. According to RM3 Labs, the mixture tops out at around 130.1 mg THC in every milliliter. There’s also a hefty dose of CBD. So just to recap: these aren’t your regular alcohol tinctures here. This is Liquid THC.

One of Canyon’s reps, Morgan Iwersen, described the taste well: “We added to cinnamon to try and downplay the taste of alcohol, but it turns out that cinnamon brings out the taste of alcohol. So this may come across as a little strong.” Strong taste, yes. If you can imagine a hardcore schnapps, made from the crappiest of vodka and sans berries, all topped off with the familiar taste of a stale, chewable antacid (extremely similar to OrganaLab’s CannaTabs), then you don’t have to rush out to buy this little gem of medicine. Then again, for 20 bucks, you get nearly twice as much mg THC than a similarly-priced Deca Dose Cheeba Chew.

But back to the taste – it’s not great. The after-taste, especially for heavy medicators, could be unbearable. Each drop tingled like Denorex shampoo and even tasted like Denorex once we started thinking about it–so much so that the back of the throat burned, and our breath transformed into wretched stench. One critic was afraid to take another dose.

Canyon’s own literature states that for best results, to take 4 drops with “a small amount of water swished around and held in your mouth for 30 seconds, thus assimilating into your blood stream without waiting for digestion.” The company reports that the bottle should contain 18 20mg doses, and that most people should take a drop every 10 minutes until feeling good. However – we read, at the bottom of the promotional materials that: “Testers start with ten drops…you’ll be glad you did.” So…we tried ten drops. 50 milligrams of liquid THC.

At first we took drops, as before, on and under the tongue (sub-lingual is a prime way to enhance the effects). After about 5 drops, it was time for an alternative method; so we tried a glass of water. The drops came out dark and spread like a food coloring, grouping itself along the edges and gooping up along the sides like an rotten egg white. Drinking the mixture prompted a gag reflex. And what remained, after the water was gone, was a sticky resinous residue, nearly impossible to remove from the cup, or the fingers, or consume. Probably could have smoked it, had we been able to scrape it off anything–but it was worse than resin.

That said – everybody felt this one working. It’s not good for an empty stomach. Canyon Cultivation has gone to great lengths to create new products…and while their Keef, Truffles, and Olive Oil have been done before to some degree, there is nothing–nothing on the market that compares to the versatility and potency of this tiny little bottle of DropIt. Our only complaint is really the flavor and aftertaste – but at least you combine the meds with applesauce or on a sandwich to hide it.

item.title: Altitude Organic Caviar
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Altitude Organic Medicine, Denver

Altitudes Caviar smokes smooth and strong, typically, and is worth the price up to $25 a gram. Once the bastion of Caviar in Colorado, Altitude was one of the first to found the Caviar staple in both advertising and experimentation. Using a unique process with the hash oil, infusion actually penetrates through the stem, enabling patients to vape even the previously-unusable parts. You can even vape the stem, the reps would say. Problem is, patients and dispensaries also began noticing an uncanny amount of stems in the caviar jars.

Altitude Organic Caviar

Perhaps due to the trade-for-bud pay arrangement between AOC and other dispensaries – or perhaps to stay competitive, some are finding a lack of quality bud underlying the oil and keef, and the dog-food appearance doesnt help any more, either. A pity, given their brand-spanking new jars and shelf presentation.

Summer 2011 Update - New York Diesel came in looking much blonder and larger than previous attempts. Much happier patients by far. Expect the standards of presentation to improve as more and more competitors enter the ring.

item.title: Sour Diesel from Good Chemistry
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Sour Diesel

Dispensary: Good Chemistry

This Sour Diesel is sour. It’s reminiscent of a strong batch of Headband going around a few months ago, and certainly doesn’t disappoint. Just like that Headband, Good Chemistry harvests their SD when the hairs are a bleach blonde, and somehow achieves a very impressive stickiness with the cure. The aroma finds a delicate marriage between a succulent flower, such as a geranium, and the stench of a beautiful woman’s armpit. Such a unique dichotomy of flavors, matched with its stark mask of hairs, makes this strain unforgettable and easy to identify.

As for effects: Very cerebral, but matched with a blaring body buzz in the extremities. A great afternoon or post-lunch snack, this one dissipates focus but relieves stress; its psychoactive trademarks shine through–it feels great to get stuff done, as long as no heavy cognitive ability is required. Good for cleaning the house on the weekend, or even hiking or rafting–this gorgeous neon bud will satisfy sativa lovers with just the perfect indica buzz, but not enough to put you down. However — if you’re the sleep-deprived type, don’t smoke SD right after a meal.

Potency was high – Good Chemistry is well known for low prices, and in general, all of their buds satisfy, at $25, every day. Since they’re a block from the capitol, make sure to stock up when you stop in; you won’t regret it. “We’re extremely busy here,” one of their bud-tenders reported. “The Sour Diesel is amazing. The Ingrid is award-winning. Everything is grown-in house and wonderful.” We definitely agree. The CannaCritics were all over 6’1” and at least 160 lbs., and experienced extreme cerebral activity after just 1-2 bong rips for a wake and bake. The initial high was eye-gauging, mouth-watering and mind-numbing. Creativity wasn’t difficult. After 2.5-3 hours, the whole buzz had disappeared, but not without a lingering tingle along the spine and at the crown of the head.

Sour Diesel is 70% Sativa. Good Chemistry tests their medical marijuana with Full Spectrum Laboratories.
item.excerpt:encoded: The aroma finds a delicate marriage between a succulent flower, such as a geranium, and the stench of a beautiful woman's armpit. Such a unique dichotomy of flavors, matched with its stark mask of hairs, makes this strain unforgettable and easy to identify. Continue reading →

item.title: Sensi Sweet Tooth from Colorado Alternative Health Care
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Sensi Sweet Tooth

Dispensary: Colorado Alternative Health Care

The breeder Spice of Life (Aka Steve) is not as well-known as fellow colleagues like DJ Short, due to somewhat limited experimentation. Sweet Tooth is one of his triumphs, though, combining exotic Grapefruit strains with Blueberry. Our sample from Alternative Health Care in Palisade was a subtle version of the hit strain and mixed with a Sensi Skunk (we presume), but potent. Its citrus aroma was overpowered by the nag champa undertones of its blueberry ancestor. As for the bud, trim was a little leafy and over-stemmed, but otherwise caked with crystals.

The first hit brushed the top of the eyebrows and palms. One hit was enough…but it took fifteen seconds to become convinced. At that point, the high crept in, sweeping through the back, up the spine and into the brain. Riveting and dizzying, the first half hour was a widening and frenzied fog encouraging movement, working functionality and general activity, but all disconnected from the outside world.

Sensi Sweet Tooth brought upon an exhilarating body high that fit as a chill-out but ultimately inspired action. There was guilty pleasure in relaxing for a movie, aggravated by a small, nagging thought that errands were left undone. Clumsiness and disorientation were noted from time to time, mostly in narcotic relief to the nerves and numbness throughout the limbs. If anything, it was a perfect balance between cerebral and body, satisfied in one large puff.

Perfect for working at night, the strain gave way when exhaustion finally set in, and helped cement the deepness of sleep. However, critics reported success by morning–with caffeine–to alleviate morning pains and soreness with an extra dose of clarity.

Despite its moniker, munchies tended more towards salty and savory, and did not cease. Midnight munchers will gain a pound and eat through the leftovers. The creeping high plateaued by 30 minutes but at a climax that lingered for at least 1 hour for high tolerance and up to 3 hours for casual patients. The bud can temporarily obliterate even the sharpest of minds, and should be sampled in moderation, especially in social situations.

Time itself warped into non-linear randomness, and punctuality was difficult. A creative strain, but not very motivational, most reports ended in a scribble; one reviewer sloppily doodled a very toothy grin.

Profile: Sativa

Testing: 18.83% Total Cannabinoids

See Full Results from Herbal Synergy

item.title: Skywalker OG from Boulder Medical Marijuana Dispensary
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Skywalker OG

Dispensary: BMMD

A typical review of Skywalker OG might reference Lando Calrissian or the Pit of Carkoon, or even related strains like Deathstar and Biggs Darklighter. But the real analogous similarity could be that of an unlikely hero, hand-picked from obscurity to save the universe…or, at least, a version of that. This mish-mash of hybrids is an alien receipe for indica excellence, matching the Mazar/Blueberry mix of Skywalker with the Lemony-Hindu Chem of OG. Whether it conjures a messianic end of the dark-side–well, that depends on your dosage.

Our latest sample came from Boulder Medical Marijuana Dispensary, tight and thick. The meaty calyxes were snow-frosted with nonchalant hairs hiding among them. She was crisp and fresh, with aromas of ginger, 7Up, and tart, chemical undertones. The first puff evoked whiplash as the nerves got their first shock. Calm and focus slowly eroded as the electricity circled round the brain, then to the rest of the body.

After a mellow five minutes, rhythmic waves of craziness arrived. And then they piled on. The body was riveted. The waves turned into shocking zaps throughout torso, then arms, and reached farther as time progressed. Across the board, unstoppable munchies raged, unyielding until about an hour and a half–when a tired, resonating descent began in the frontal lobe. The eyes were heavy and we lost momentum quickly from then on.

For all of us, both social conversation skills, and confidence, shattered. Creativity came, but in the non-sober sense. Numbers, calculations, and intelligent tasks were impossible. We were inspired, namely, to avoid work. It was a great selection for sledding or an afternoon with the kite. She was an indica for immediate pain relief but not immediate sleep. Skywalker OG sleep will come, but not until after a game, puzzle, movie, or date.

One puff of the Skywalker OG turned out to be the perfect dose for daytime functionality, but 2 puffs was a gamble; too much is too much, and the low-tolerance novices will embarrass themselves. Doses should be spaced apart to avoid spilling past the threshold, as she was one of the most comprehensive indicas weve reviewed in a while. Overall, the experience was temperate yet hopeful, and critics described their emotions as friendly, diplomatic, and Rockin–worthy of Ray Charles.

Profile: Indica Dominant

Testing: 16.8% Total Cannabinoids

See Full Results from Herbal Synergy

item.title: How Cannapages Judges Edibles
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
The FIVE Ps
The Hallmark of a Staple Edible, to Cannapages.com:
A good edible doesnt require the whole package to be consumed. We typically insist on eating the whole package unless absolutely necessary, regardless. But a staple edible should not have a short shelf life. It should not require refrigeration, stirring, shaking, preparation, etc.
It should not be a food that consumers wont purchase on a normal basis. Goods that fly off the shelf at grocery stores or holiday party platters work the best. Word of mouth should precede the item (regarding its potency), and first glance should sell it.
That given, a staple edible cant be sold at a price that doesnt match the appearance, without proper explanation or hype. Potency must be explicitly portrayed on the label, especially for small objects. Otherwise, the edible should be very, very presentable, as to guise the hand-production (almost guaranteed at this stage in the industry). It should not be broken, leaking in any way, exposed whatsoever to light or air, smudged, too gooey or too dry. Packaging should be as clean-cut as possible; colors work best in the product and on the label; earth-tones always sell slower.
But most of all, a staple edible must be one that can be consumed day in and day out, or at least in rotation with a small handful of other staples. Whereas a person may not mind tossing a few slightly-offbeat culinary bits into their routine for medication purposes, they will not start directing their diet or snacking habits based on an edibles purchase. You cant expect to sell salsa, cornbread, or even ice cream on a regular basis, because a patient doesnt always carry chips with which to dip the salsa, or have a microwave to warm up todays bite of week-old corn bread, or have to access their ice cream in the freezer when theyre sitting in the library or on a bus. Customers who DO routinely buy one certain niche dietary item from their grocer, will probably find its medicated equivalent enticing at the dispensary. But even then, they may prefer the natural, non-canna version and depend on a completely different type of food or drink. Its not an easy thing to predict.
Ultimately, practicality, price, potency, presentation, and finally, palate, all go into an edibles potential to rise the ranks from generic to staple.

item.title: Benjamins Edibles Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Benilla Wafers: The Benilla Wafers make a good staple. Not to mention, a great improvement on an already great cookie, the vanilla wafer. Sandwiched together between two wafers, the green cannacream hits fairly hard and fast. Slight lemony taste to the cream; addictive and worth eating the whole bag. CannaStats: “100 mg THC” per bag (4 cookies at ~ 25mg each)
Ow-Wee-Ohs: Although the edges always seem to crack off, these large chocolate cookie sandwiches with their signature green Benjamin cream, are the decadent improvement on Oreos. Granted most oreo-based edibles simply consist of the original cookie encased in chocolate, but Benjamins wanted to actually reinvent it altogether. Each cookie sports 50 mg apiece, but only two come to a package. Good luck dosing with this one. CannaStats: “100 mg THC” per bag (2 cookies sandwiches)
Bank Rolls: Not necessarily an improvement on the Cheeba Chew potency, but at least with the taste. Of all the alternative versions of the Cheeba Chew, this one is far most requested. The biggest seller is the taste, more of an orange-based spice and cleaner tasting, without the sharp, pungent undertones associated with Cheebas. Toting 100mg, this seems a formidable opponent (especially for the same retail price, typically). The only things missing are the 3- or 5-pack versions (not to mention hybrid, indica, and sativa distinction). CannaStats: “100 Mg” per roll (compare to 70 mg Quad Dose Cheeba Chews)

Gum: Because its sloshing around your mouth capillaries for so long, this little guy gets right on top of you. It also tastes better than most other gums–but theres nothing to prevent it from losing all taste after 10 minutes. The question is: when is it okay to spit out gum that cost 3 bucks? Thankfully, with 50 mg distributed in a fat, large piece, youll have no problem dosing. Not a good method for night time medicating, though. Benjamin’s downfall was coming out with both 25 and 50 mg versions, which often overlap in pricing on the shelves and/or confuse customers and their bud-tenders.

item.title: Simply Pure Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Gourmet of the Gourmet: Peppermint Cups, Peanut Brittle, Coconut Almond Cups, Sesame Brittle and Granola Bars – phew. Simply Pure is certainly a shrugger as far as Edibles go, just like Whole Foods might be, for a hipster strapped for cash. On the one hand, theyre the brainchild of 8 Rivers Master Chef Scott Durrah and Mad Batter’s Lauren Gennett, and distributed by some of the coolest vendors in the industry. On the other hand, you can only sell $15 Peanut Brittle to a select crowd. The same with a granola bar, especially when the Buddha bar selling off the shelves at such a lower price. Granted, their gourmet chocolates really are gourmet, but even the most gourmet chocolates wont sell to people who dont buy them normally. One thing SP does well is presentation –good product packaging and photography . Then again, youll look at the sesame brittle and ask, Im paying $16 bucks for what? Dosaging: Be forewarned that you cant eat simply pure on an empty stomach–and the chocolates (especially the peppermint cups) are so rich that youll probably have to have something salty nearby to get it down. The record for dosing on this one was 3 packages on an empty stomach – to which the reviewer remarked,I dont know if I feel anything, do you?.

CannaStats: 100mg THC Per Package as advertised. Peppermint cups: around 38mg THC. Granola Bars ~36mg THC. Peanut Brittle Bar ~ STUNNING 71.46 mg THC. Sesame Brittle ~ 54.76 mg THC. Coconut Cups ~ 35.5 mg THC.

Industry Hint: Simply Pure has some big, big things planned for later this year – with not only better and more practical items on the menu, but smaller and more affordable versions of their original line.

item.title: Dixie Elixirs Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded: Elixirs: Once dubbed the more expensive, less effective version of Keef, Dixie Elixirs has come a long way from their hand-bottled days. Although some batches have been spotted with gritty residues at the top of bottles, the general consensus nowadays is that Dixie packs twice the punch of a regular Keef for a similar price (regardless what labels say), and is the better bang-for-buck. Their syrups are special-made out of Cali (including an original Sarsaparilla, whatever that tastes like). Their award winning Blueberry soda is winner among patients; orange tastes perhaps the least medicated. Between Peach, mandarin, and pomegranate, you wont likely be disappointed. Don’t drink until after cold.

item.title: Dazys Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Candies: Dazys flower-shaped candies were the first well-branded hard candies on the market, and to a certain degree, they still are. While they still make a rainbow of colorful varieties, including the best sugar-free version we know of, its been a while since they made a disctinction between certain potency levels for their candies. Not that it would make a difference. The candies have gone downhill since their inception, and patients arent asking for them anymore. Not to mention their cumbersome nature; like Willy Wonkas onscreen gobstoppers, you cant have a conversation, barely swallow juices, and pretty much have to bite the thing in half to keep from drooling on yourself. The price is still good – but not sure if these delicious candies still have the same allure they once did. Then again, there are those who swear by them. CannaStats: 100mg Cannabis Extract (CO2/H2O Extraction From 2.4g Strong Marijuana)

Caps:The best cap, hands down. An expensive one. Hits you hard the first time, the highest youve been in a long, long time. Not for the faint of heart, especially if eaten on an empty stomach. Even for those with high tolerances, the first time will hit you hard, starting with a gut-dropping sensation (free-fall, whether youve eaten or not) and grow into a hardcore high with riveting peaks, climaxing somewhere around hour 3-4 and then coming down accordingly. This, unlike so many other hash cap doses is only a pill for big medicators, and even then, only when you have time to be taken of out commission. CannaStats: 170mg Hash Oil (!)

item.title: Bakked Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded: Tie-Dyed Cookies – Bakkeds Tie-Dyed Cookies may be the worst baked good we have ever tasted, even worse than if the recipe’s ingredients were extracted and consumed raw. While the bakers were shooting for sugar cookie, what they inevitably produced actually tastes like paint-cookie, only less tart. And they created a sandwich, on top of everything! To throw a frosting between two paint cookies – nay, to include four cookies in the package, total – means 2-4 excruciating doses. It was an experience bad enough to make us avoid Bakkeds other products for good. CannaStats: Contains67mg THC per package, but not worth it.

item.title: Mountain High Suckers
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Mountain High Suckers: Patients have remarked that the suckers are actually as strong as advertised. We certainly concur. With more CBD than almost any other edible – and a research team that constantly tests their competitors – the Mountain High team sticks to the basics but have developed a unique, signature style of impeccable taste and generous cannabinoid content. Also inviting is a mouth-watering presentation: the pineapple-coconut actually has toasted coconut shavings sprinkled delicately along the faade, and other fruity flavors sport their dried derivatives. Overwhelmingly, the blueberry sucker is most sought-after, followed by butterscotch, watermelon, strawberry, tangerine, and more.
CannaStats: 11.7mg THC and a STUNNING 17.69mg CBD

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Gaias Garden, Granny Ts, Sweet Palliatives
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Gaia’s Garden
Zonkey Bar – The Zonkey bar does not sell that well. Its a combination of chocolate, almonds, cranberries, and pumpkin seeds, ultimately creating a questionable sweet taste in your mouth, and probably not enough to bring you back.
PB Blaster – The blaster works because its almost all medicated peanut butter. Essentially a fat, clump of Reeses, but better. That said, its difficult to not eat the whole thing in one fell swoop, especially with the little messiness. Then again, if youre not the kind of person who can easily down 2 Reeses cups consecutively–and especially if you cant handle a plain ol heaping spoonful of pure peanut butter alone–this will probably be too much.
Cloud 9 Bar and Balls – A dwarfed version of the larger and long-retired cloud 9 bars, these little guys pack a punch of THC and sugar. Nothing like chocolate, marshmallows, caramel, pretzels and coconut oil to invigorate the senses. Buy this when its on sale, for $3 or $4 bucks max.
Nookie Cookies - Two heart-shaped cookies. Kind of grainy and plain, but with a little hint of cranberry. Perfect for the vegan in your life.
Razzle Dazzle – The worst part of this bar is that it is white chocolate. White Chocolate lovers will love the white chocolate, but then youll have the problem of dosage compared to price. Gaias Gardens bars have almost always been known for their lower potency (Level 4 equals what, precisely?) and its that thick veil that seems to keep people from coming back. While this bar tastes good–dont buy it unless youre a white chocolate lover to start, and one with lower tolerance.
Almondeus, Milk & Dark – The almond glaze in the middle of the chocolate tastes okay, a moderate almond taste with a very moderate THC chocolate. Almondeus werent always Level 4 bars, to our best memory, but since becoming a Level 4, we havent felt any difference.
Harlequin Bar - Cayenne pepper infused chocolate sounds great, especially with a caramel center, but really isnt anything to write home about. The most annoying part of such an expensive bar, is the fact that you dont feel it very much either.
Rainbow Kaos Krunch - If you didnt think Fruity Pebbles could get any richer, encase a brick of the cereal in milk chocolate with coconut oil. Your tongue will hardly be able to handle the circus in your mouth. I didnt always feel the effects of this – so I gave it to another patient, a burly 230-pound guy whose tolerance was even higher than mine. He reported that it took him out for 10 hours, curiously enough. Another example of how edibles hit everyone differently.
CannaFish – Hard Candy fish in variety of flavors. Comes in 2x or 3x strengths – or at least, did – but not a very patient-appreciated candy line. Plays a second string to Dazys and most suckers. 

Granny Ts
Righteous Krispie Bar - This is not the most impressive cereal bar, but does involve a layer of chocolate. Not sure what else to say. Its a Rice Krispie bar with fairly moderate effect and a layer of freakin chocolate. Good luck fitting it in your mouth.
Peanut Brittle - Unlike other medible Peanut Brittle, often golden and loafed and gourmet-weird, Granny T presents the real thing, harkening to most holiday peanut brittles Ive ever seen. Its familiar. The problem is, how used to buying peanut brittle am I?
Lemon Bar - Definitely the hallmark of a Granny T edible, the Lemon bar looks like the exact replica of a Sunday-brunch-in-the-church-basement dessert, complete with the powdered sugar lining the meringue, and a perfectly powdery pastry crust.

OMG Peanut Butter Cookies – This is a no-brainer edible, a staple, a shelf-stuffer and patient-favorite. Thing is, the peanut butter cookie with Hershey kiss is the most important thing on a cookie platter, the first to go. And while Gaias Garden seemed to commit a bakers faux pas by inverting the chocolate kiss, the move hasnt permanently affected sales (although a pointy kiss seems to sell the cookie). In a retail atmosphere where brown does not sell well, this cookie somehow sells 2 or 3 at a time.

Zesty Crackers – These soup crackers dont have any effect whatsoever–unless youre the kind of person to eat a full bag of soup crackers. Assuming most patients will buy actual food before medicine, no one will be starving enough to try medicating in this absurdly wasteful fashion.

Kettle Chips – By far the worst selling item youll ever see on a dispensary shelf, these Kettle chips are over-salted, glycerin-dipped spuds, but at least have an undeniable effect (all that soaking in Canna-grease really pays off). As far as a shelf-life, these things will sit forever and ruin, simply due to their presentation. Theres a reason you dont buy cheese kettle crackers in a clear plastic bag–they look like the kind of thing Bruce Brodie would wipe his hands with to give a Mallrat diarrhea. Seriously, there is nothing appetizing about the sight of these chips, but if youre into couch-crashing with lots of beer on a Saturday afternoon, they may fit right in.
item.excerpt:encoded: Gaia’s Garden Zonkey Bar – The Zonkey bar does not sell that well. Its a combination of chocolate, almonds, cranberries, and pumpkin seeds, ultimately creating a questionable sweet taste in your mouth, and probably not enough to bring you back. … Continue reading →

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: How Cannapages Judges Edibles
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
The FIVE Ps
The Hallmark of a Staple Edible, to Cannapages.com:
A good edible doesnt require the whole package to be consumed. We typically insist on eating the whole package unless absolutely necessary, regardless. But a staple edible should not have a short shelf life. It should not require refrigeration, stirring, shaking, preparation, etc.
It should not be a food that consumers wont purchase on a normal basis. Goods that fly off the shelf at grocery stores or holiday party platters work the best. Word of mouth should precede the item (regarding its potency), and first glance should sell it.
That given, a staple edible cant be sold at a price that doesnt match the appearance, without proper explanation or hype. Potency must be explicitly portrayed on the label, especially for small objects. Otherwise, the edible should be very, very presentable, as to guise the hand-production (almost guaranteed at this stage in the industry). It should not be broken, leaking in any way, exposed whatsoever to light or air, smudged, too gooey or too dry. Packaging should be as clean-cut as possible; colors work best in the product and on the label; earth-tones always sell slower.
But most of all, a staple edible must be one that can be consumed day in and day out, or at least in rotation with a small handful of other staples. Whereas a person may not mind tossing a few slightly-offbeat culinary bits into their routine for medication purposes, they will not start directing their diet or snacking habits based on an edibles purchase. You cant expect to sell salsa, cornbread, or even ice cream on a regular basis, because a patient doesnt always carry chips with which to dip the salsa, or have a microwave to warm up todays bite of week-old corn bread, or have to access their ice cream in the freezer when theyre sitting in the library or on a bus. Customers who DO routinely buy one certain niche dietary item from their grocer, will probably find its medicated equivalent enticing at the dispensary. But even then, they may prefer the natural, non-canna version and depend on a completely different type of food or drink. Its not an easy thing to predict.
Ultimately, practicality, price, potency, presentation, and finally, palate, all go into an edibles potential to rise the ranks from generic to staple.
item.excerpt:encoded: The FIVE Ps The Hallmark of a Staple Edible, to Cannapages.com: A good edible doesnt require the whole package to be consumed. We typically insist on eating the whole package unless absolutely necessary, regardless. But a staple edible should not … Continue reading →

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Benjamins Edibles Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Benilla Wafers: The Benilla Wafers make a good staple. Not to mention, a great improvement on an already great cookie, the vanilla wafer. Sandwiched together between two wafers, the green cannacream hits fairly hard and fast. Slight lemony taste to the cream; addictive and worth eating the whole bag. CannaStats: “100 mg THC” per bag (4 cookies at ~ 25mg each)
Ow-Wee-Ohs: Although the edges always seem to crack off, these large chocolate cookie sandwiches with their signature green Benjamin cream, are the decadent improvement on Oreos. Granted most oreo-based edibles simply consist of the original cookie encased in chocolate, but Benjamins wanted to actually reinvent it altogether. Each cookie sports 50 mg apiece, but only two come to a package. Good luck dosing with this one. CannaStats: “100 mg THC” per bag (2 cookies sandwiches)
Bank Rolls: Not necessarily an improvement on the Cheeba Chew potency, but at least with the taste. Of all the alternative versions of the Cheeba Chew, this one is far most requested. The biggest seller is the taste, more of an orange-based spice and cleaner tasting, without the sharp, pungent undertones associated with Cheebas. Toting 100mg, this seems a formidable opponent (especially for the same retail price, typically). The only things missing are the 3- or 5-pack versions (not to mention hybrid, indica, and sativa distinction). CannaStats: “100 Mg” per roll (compare to 70 mg Quad Dose Cheeba Chews)

Gum: Because its sloshing around your mouth capillaries for so long, this little guy gets right on top of you. It also tastes better than most other gums–but theres nothing to prevent it from losing all taste after 10 minutes. The question is: when is it okay to spit out gum that cost 3 bucks? Thankfully, with 50 mg distributed in a fat, large piece, youll have no problem dosing. Not a good method for night time medicating, though. Benjamin’s downfall was coming out with both 25 and 50 mg versions, which often overlap in pricing on the shelves and/or confuse customers and their bud-tenders.
item.excerpt:encoded: Benilla Wafers: The Benilla Wafers make a good staple. Not to mention, a great improvement on an already great cookie, the vanilla wafer. Sandwiched together between two wafers, the green cannacream hits fairly hard and fast. Slight lemony taste to … Continue reading →

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Simply Pure Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Gourmet of the Gourmet: Peppermint Cups, Peanut Brittle, Coconut Almond Cups, Sesame Brittle and Granola Bars – phew. Simply Pure is certainly a shrugger as far as Edibles go, just like Whole Foods might be, for a hipster strapped for cash. On the one hand, theyre the brainchild of 8 Rivers Master Chef Scott Durrah and Mad Batter’s Lauren Gennett, and distributed by some of the coolest vendors in the industry. On the other hand, you can only sell $15 Peanut Brittle to a select crowd. The same with a granola bar, especially when the Buddha bar selling off the shelves at such a lower price. Granted, their gourmet chocolates really are gourmet, but even the most gourmet chocolates wont sell to people who dont buy them normally. One thing SP does well is presentation –good product packaging and photography . Then again, youll look at the sesame brittle and ask, Im paying $16 bucks for what? Dosaging: Be forewarned that you cant eat simply pure on an empty stomach–and the chocolates (especially the peppermint cups) are so rich that youll probably have to have something salty nearby to get it down. The record for dosing on this one was 3 packages on an empty stomach – to which the reviewer remarked,I dont know if I feel anything, do you?.

CannaStats: 100mg THC Per Package as advertised. Peppermint cups: around 38mg THC. Granola Bars ~36mg THC. Peanut Brittle Bar ~ STUNNING 71.46 mg THC. Sesame Brittle ~ 54.76 mg THC. Coconut Cups ~ 35.5 mg THC.

Industry Hint: Simply Pure has some big, big things planned for later this year – with not only better and more practical items on the menu, but smaller and more affordable versions of their original line.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Dixie Elixirs Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded: Elixirs: Once dubbed the more expensive, less effective version of Keef, Dixie Elixirs has come a long way from their hand-bottled days. Although some batches have been spotted with gritty residues at the top of bottles, the general consensus nowadays is that Dixie packs twice the punch of a regular Keef for a similar price (regardless what labels say), and is the better bang-for-buck. Their syrups are special-made out of Cali (including an original Sarsaparilla, whatever that tastes like). Their award winning Blueberry soda is winner among patients; orange tastes perhaps the least medicated. Between Peach, mandarin, and pomegranate, you wont likely be disappointed. Don’t drink until after cold.
item.excerpt:encoded: Elixirs: Once dubbed the more expensive, less effective version of Keef, Dixie Elixirs has come a long way from their hand-bottled days. Although some batches have been spotted with gritty residues at the top of bottles, the general consensus nowadays … Continue reading →

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Dazys Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Candies: Dazys flower-shaped candies were the first well-branded hard candies on the market, and to a certain degree, they still are. While they still make a rainbow of colorful varieties, including the best sugar-free version we know of, its been a while since they made a disctinction between certain potency levels for their candies. Not that it would make a difference. The candies have gone downhill since their inception, and patients arent asking for them anymore. Not to mention their cumbersome nature; like Willy Wonkas onscreen gobstoppers, you cant have a conversation, barely swallow juices, and pretty much have to bite the thing in half to keep from drooling on yourself. The price is still good – but not sure if these delicious candies still have the same allure they once did. Then again, there are those who swear by them. CannaStats: 100mg Cannabis Extract (CO2/H2O Extraction From 2.4g Strong Marijuana)

Caps:The best cap, hands down. An expensive one. Hits you hard the first time, the highest youve been in a long, long time. Not for the faint of heart, especially if eaten on an empty stomach. Even for those with high tolerances, the first time will hit you hard, starting with a gut-dropping sensation (free-fall, whether youve eaten or not) and grow into a hardcore high with riveting peaks, climaxing somewhere around hour 3-4 and then coming down accordingly. This, unlike so many other hash cap doses is only a pill for big medicators, and even then, only when you have time to be taken of out commission. CannaStats: 170mg Hash Oil (!)
item.excerpt:encoded: Candies: Dazys flower-shaped candies were the first well-branded hard candies on the market, and to a certain degree, they still are. While they still make a rainbow of colorful varieties, including the best sugar-free version we know of, its been … Continue reading →

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Mountain High Suckers
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Mountain High Suckers: Patients have remarked that the suckers are actually as strong as advertised. We certainly concur. With more CBD than almost any other edible – and a research team that constantly tests their competitors – the Mountain High team sticks to the basics but have developed a unique, signature style of impeccable taste and generous cannabinoid content. Also inviting is a mouth-watering presentation: the pineapple-coconut actually has toasted coconut shavings sprinkled delicately along the faade, and other fruity flavors sport their dried derivatives. Overwhelmingly, the blueberry sucker is most sought-after, followed by butterscotch, watermelon, strawberry, tangerine, and more.
CannaStats: 11.7mg THC and a STUNNING 17.69mg CBD

item.title: Gaias Garden, Granny Ts, Sweet Palliatives
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Gaia’s Garden
Zonkey Bar – The Zonkey bar does not sell that well. Its a combination of chocolate, almonds, cranberries, and pumpkin seeds, ultimately creating a questionable sweet taste in your mouth, and probably not enough to bring you back.
PB Blaster – The blaster works because its almost all medicated peanut butter. Essentially a fat, clump of Reeses, but better. That said, its difficult to not eat the whole thing in one fell swoop, especially with the little messiness. Then again, if youre not the kind of person who can easily down 2 Reeses cups consecutively–and especially if you cant handle a plain ol heaping spoonful of pure peanut butter alone–this will probably be too much.
Cloud 9 Bar and Balls – A dwarfed version of the larger and long-retired cloud 9 bars, these little guys pack a punch of THC and sugar. Nothing like chocolate, marshmallows, caramel, pretzels and coconut oil to invigorate the senses. Buy this when its on sale, for $3 or $4 bucks max.
Nookie Cookies - Two heart-shaped cookies. Kind of grainy and plain, but with a little hint of cranberry. Perfect for the vegan in your life.
Razzle Dazzle – The worst part of this bar is that it is white chocolate. White Chocolate lovers will love the white chocolate, but then youll have the problem of dosage compared to price. Gaias Gardens bars have almost always been known for their lower potency (Level 4 equals what, precisely?) and its that thick veil that seems to keep people from coming back. While this bar tastes good–dont buy it unless youre a white chocolate lover to start, and one with lower tolerance.
Almondeus, Milk & Dark – The almond glaze in the middle of the chocolate tastes okay, a moderate almond taste with a very moderate THC chocolate. Almondeus werent always Level 4 bars, to our best memory, but since becoming a Level 4, we havent felt any difference.
Harlequin Bar - Cayenne pepper infused chocolate sounds great, especially with a caramel center, but really isnt anything to write home about. The most annoying part of such an expensive bar, is the fact that you dont feel it very much either.
Rainbow Kaos Krunch - If you didnt think Fruity Pebbles could get any richer, encase a brick of the cereal in milk chocolate with coconut oil. Your tongue will hardly be able to handle the circus in your mouth. I didnt always feel the effects of this – so I gave it to another patient, a burly 230-pound guy whose tolerance was even higher than mine. He reported that it took him out for 10 hours, curiously enough. Another example of how edibles hit everyone differently.
CannaFish – Hard Candy fish in variety of flavors. Comes in 2x or 3x strengths – or at least, did – but not a very patient-appreciated candy line. Plays a second string to Dazys and most suckers. 

Granny Ts
Righteous Krispie Bar - This is not the most impressive cereal bar, but does involve a layer of chocolate. Not sure what else to say. Its a Rice Krispie bar with fairly moderate effect and a layer of freakin chocolate. Good luck fitting it in your mouth.
Peanut Brittle - Unlike other medible Peanut Brittle, often golden and loafed and gourmet-weird, Granny T presents the real thing, harkening to most holiday peanut brittles Ive ever seen. Its familiar. The problem is, how used to buying peanut brittle am I?
Lemon Bar - Definitely the hallmark of a Granny T edible, the Lemon bar looks like the exact replica of a Sunday-brunch-in-the-church-basement dessert, complete with the powdered sugar lining the meringue, and a perfectly powdery pastry crust.

OMG Peanut Butter Cookies – This is a no-brainer edible, a staple, a shelf-stuffer and patient-favorite. Thing is, the peanut butter cookie with Hershey kiss is the most important thing on a cookie platter, the first to go. And while Gaias Garden seemed to commit a bakers faux pas by inverting the chocolate kiss, the move hasnt permanently affected sales (although a pointy kiss seems to sell the cookie). In a retail atmosphere where brown does not sell well, this cookie somehow sells 2 or 3 at a time.

Zesty Crackers – These soup crackers dont have any effect whatsoever–unless youre the kind of person to eat a full bag of soup crackers. Assuming most patients will buy actual food before medicine, no one will be starving enough to try medicating in this absurdly wasteful fashion.

Kettle Chips – By far the worst selling item youll ever see on a dispensary shelf, these Kettle chips are over-salted, glycerin-dipped spuds, but at least have an undeniable effect (all that soaking in Canna-grease really pays off). As far as a shelf-life, these things will sit forever and ruin, simply due to their presentation. Theres a reason you dont buy cheese kettle crackers in a clear plastic bag–they look like the kind of thing Bruce Brodie would wipe his hands with to give a Mallrat diarrhea. Seriously, there is nothing appetizing about the sight of these chips, but if youre into couch-crashing with lots of beer on a Saturday afternoon, they may fit right in.

item.title: Bakked Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded: Tie-Dyed Cookies – Bakkeds Tie-Dyed Cookies may be the worst baked good we have ever tasted, even worse than if the recipe’s ingredients were extracted and consumed raw. While the bakers were shooting for sugar cookie, what they inevitably produced actually tastes like paint-cookie, only less tart. And they created a sandwich, on top of everything! To throw a frosting between two paint cookies – nay, to include four cookies in the package, total – means 2-4 excruciating doses. It was an experience bad enough to make us avoid Bakkeds other products for good. CannaStats: Contains67mg THC per package, but not worth it.

item.title: Mountain High Suckers
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Mountain High Suckers: Patients have remarked that the suckers are actually as strong as advertised. We certainly concur. With more CBD than almost any other edible – and a research team that constantly tests their competitors – the Mountain High team sticks to the basics but have developed a unique, signature style of impeccable taste and generous cannabinoid content. Also inviting is a mouth-watering presentation: the pineapple-coconut actually has toasted coconut shavings sprinkled delicately along the faade, and other fruity flavors sport their dried derivatives. Overwhelmingly, the blueberry sucker is most sought-after, followed by butterscotch, watermelon, strawberry, tangerine, and more.
CannaStats: 11.7mg THC and a STUNNING 17.69mg CBD

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Gaias Garden, Granny Ts, Sweet Palliatives
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Gaia’s Garden
Zonkey Bar – The Zonkey bar does not sell that well. Its a combination of chocolate, almonds, cranberries, and pumpkin seeds, ultimately creating a questionable sweet taste in your mouth, and probably not enough to bring you back.
PB Blaster – The blaster works because its almost all medicated peanut butter. Essentially a fat, clump of Reeses, but better. That said, its difficult to not eat the whole thing in one fell swoop, especially with the little messiness. Then again, if youre not the kind of person who can easily down 2 Reeses cups consecutively–and especially if you cant handle a plain ol heaping spoonful of pure peanut butter alone–this will probably be too much.
Cloud 9 Bar and Balls – A dwarfed version of the larger and long-retired cloud 9 bars, these little guys pack a punch of THC and sugar. Nothing like chocolate, marshmallows, caramel, pretzels and coconut oil to invigorate the senses. Buy this when its on sale, for $3 or $4 bucks max.
Nookie Cookies - Two heart-shaped cookies. Kind of grainy and plain, but with a little hint of cranberry. Perfect for the vegan in your life.
Razzle Dazzle – The worst part of this bar is that it is white chocolate. White Chocolate lovers will love the white chocolate, but then youll have the problem of dosage compared to price. Gaias Gardens bars have almost always been known for their lower potency (Level 4 equals what, precisely?) and its that thick veil that seems to keep people from coming back. While this bar tastes good–dont buy it unless youre a white chocolate lover to start, and one with lower tolerance.
Almondeus, Milk & Dark – The almond glaze in the middle of the chocolate tastes okay, a moderate almond taste with a very moderate THC chocolate. Almondeus werent always Level 4 bars, to our best memory, but since becoming a Level 4, we havent felt any difference.
Harlequin Bar - Cayenne pepper infused chocolate sounds great, especially with a caramel center, but really isnt anything to write home about. The most annoying part of such an expensive bar, is the fact that you dont feel it very much either.
Rainbow Kaos Krunch - If you didnt think Fruity Pebbles could get any richer, encase a brick of the cereal in milk chocolate with coconut oil. Your tongue will hardly be able to handle the circus in your mouth. I didnt always feel the effects of this – so I gave it to another patient, a burly 230-pound guy whose tolerance was even higher than mine. He reported that it took him out for 10 hours, curiously enough. Another example of how edibles hit everyone differently.
CannaFish – Hard Candy fish in variety of flavors. Comes in 2x or 3x strengths – or at least, did – but not a very patient-appreciated candy line. Plays a second string to Dazys and most suckers. 

Granny Ts
Righteous Krispie Bar - This is not the most impressive cereal bar, but does involve a layer of chocolate. Not sure what else to say. Its a Rice Krispie bar with fairly moderate effect and a layer of freakin chocolate. Good luck fitting it in your mouth.
Peanut Brittle - Unlike other medible Peanut Brittle, often golden and loafed and gourmet-weird, Granny T presents the real thing, harkening to most holiday peanut brittles Ive ever seen. Its familiar. The problem is, how used to buying peanut brittle am I?
Lemon Bar - Definitely the hallmark of a Granny T edible, the Lemon bar looks like the exact replica of a Sunday-brunch-in-the-church-basement dessert, complete with the powdered sugar lining the meringue, and a perfectly powdery pastry crust.

OMG Peanut Butter Cookies – This is a no-brainer edible, a staple, a shelf-stuffer and patient-favorite. Thing is, the peanut butter cookie with Hershey kiss is the most important thing on a cookie platter, the first to go. And while Gaias Garden seemed to commit a bakers faux pas by inverting the chocolate kiss, the move hasnt permanently affected sales (although a pointy kiss seems to sell the cookie). In a retail atmosphere where brown does not sell well, this cookie somehow sells 2 or 3 at a time.

Zesty Crackers – These soup crackers dont have any effect whatsoever–unless youre the kind of person to eat a full bag of soup crackers. Assuming most patients will buy actual food before medicine, no one will be starving enough to try medicating in this absurdly wasteful fashion.

Kettle Chips – By far the worst selling item youll ever see on a dispensary shelf, these Kettle chips are over-salted, glycerin-dipped spuds, but at least have an undeniable effect (all that soaking in Canna-grease really pays off). As far as a shelf-life, these things will sit forever and ruin, simply due to their presentation. Theres a reason you dont buy cheese kettle crackers in a clear plastic bag–they look like the kind of thing Bruce Brodie would wipe his hands with to give a Mallrat diarrhea. Seriously, there is nothing appetizing about the sight of these chips, but if youre into couch-crashing with lots of beer on a Saturday afternoon, they may fit right in.

item.title: How Cannapages Judges Edibles
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
The FIVE Ps
The Hallmark of a Staple Edible, to Cannapages.com:
A good edible doesnt require the whole package to be consumed. We typically insist on eating the whole package unless absolutely necessary, regardless. But a staple edible should not have a short shelf life. It should not require refrigeration, stirring, shaking, preparation, etc.
It should not be a food that consumers wont purchase on a normal basis. Goods that fly off the shelf at grocery stores or holiday party platters work the best. Word of mouth should precede the item (regarding its potency), and first glance should sell it.
That given, a staple edible cant be sold at a price that doesnt match the appearance, without proper explanation or hype. Potency must be explicitly portrayed on the label, especially for small objects. Otherwise, the edible should be very, very presentable, as to guise the hand-production (almost guaranteed at this stage in the industry). It should not be broken, leaking in any way, exposed whatsoever to light or air, smudged, too gooey or too dry. Packaging should be as clean-cut as possible; colors work best in the product and on the label; earth-tones always sell slower.
But most of all, a staple edible must be one that can be consumed day in and day out, or at least in rotation with a small handful of other staples. Whereas a person may not mind tossing a few slightly-offbeat culinary bits into their routine for medication purposes, they will not start directing their diet or snacking habits based on an edibles purchase. You cant expect to sell salsa, cornbread, or even ice cream on a regular basis, because a patient doesnt always carry chips with which to dip the salsa, or have a microwave to warm up todays bite of week-old corn bread, or have to access their ice cream in the freezer when theyre sitting in the library or on a bus. Customers who DO routinely buy one certain niche dietary item from their grocer, will probably find its medicated equivalent enticing at the dispensary. But even then, they may prefer the natural, non-canna version and depend on a completely different type of food or drink. Its not an easy thing to predict.
Ultimately, practicality, price, potency, presentation, and finally, palate, all go into an edibles potential to rise the ranks from generic to staple.

item.title: Benjamins Edibles Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Benilla Wafers: The Benilla Wafers make a good staple. Not to mention, a great improvement on an already great cookie, the vanilla wafer. Sandwiched together between two wafers, the green cannacream hits fairly hard and fast. Slight lemony taste to the cream; addictive and worth eating the whole bag. CannaStats: “100 mg THC” per bag (4 cookies at ~ 25mg each)
Ow-Wee-Ohs: Although the edges always seem to crack off, these large chocolate cookie sandwiches with their signature green Benjamin cream, are the decadent improvement on Oreos. Granted most oreo-based edibles simply consist of the original cookie encased in chocolate, but Benjamins wanted to actually reinvent it altogether. Each cookie sports 50 mg apiece, but only two come to a package. Good luck dosing with this one. CannaStats: “100 mg THC” per bag (2 cookies sandwiches)
Bank Rolls: Not necessarily an improvement on the Cheeba Chew potency, but at least with the taste. Of all the alternative versions of the Cheeba Chew, this one is far most requested. The biggest seller is the taste, more of an orange-based spice and cleaner tasting, without the sharp, pungent undertones associated with Cheebas. Toting 100mg, this seems a formidable opponent (especially for the same retail price, typically). The only things missing are the 3- or 5-pack versions (not to mention hybrid, indica, and sativa distinction). CannaStats: “100 Mg” per roll (compare to 70 mg Quad Dose Cheeba Chews)

Gum: Because its sloshing around your mouth capillaries for so long, this little guy gets right on top of you. It also tastes better than most other gums–but theres nothing to prevent it from losing all taste after 10 minutes. The question is: when is it okay to spit out gum that cost 3 bucks? Thankfully, with 50 mg distributed in a fat, large piece, youll have no problem dosing. Not a good method for night time medicating, though. Benjamin’s downfall was coming out with both 25 and 50 mg versions, which often overlap in pricing on the shelves and/or confuse customers and their bud-tenders.
item.excerpt:encoded: Benilla Wafers: The Benilla Wafers make a good staple. Not to mention, a great improvement on an already great cookie, the vanilla wafer. Sandwiched together between two wafers, the green cannacream hits fairly hard and fast. Slight lemony taste to … Continue reading →

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Simply Pure Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Gourmet of the Gourmet: Peppermint Cups, Peanut Brittle, Coconut Almond Cups, Sesame Brittle and Granola Bars – phew. Simply Pure is certainly a shrugger as far as Edibles go, just like Whole Foods might be, for a hipster strapped for cash. On the one hand, theyre the brainchild of 8 Rivers Master Chef Scott Durrah and Mad Batter’s Lauren Gennett, and distributed by some of the coolest vendors in the industry. On the other hand, you can only sell $15 Peanut Brittle to a select crowd. The same with a granola bar, especially when the Buddha bar selling off the shelves at such a lower price. Granted, their gourmet chocolates really are gourmet, but even the most gourmet chocolates wont sell to people who dont buy them normally. One thing SP does well is presentation –good product packaging and photography . Then again, youll look at the sesame brittle and ask, Im paying $16 bucks for what? Dosaging: Be forewarned that you cant eat simply pure on an empty stomach–and the chocolates (especially the peppermint cups) are so rich that youll probably have to have something salty nearby to get it down. The record for dosing on this one was 3 packages on an empty stomach – to which the reviewer remarked,I dont know if I feel anything, do you?.

CannaStats: 100mg THC Per Package as advertised. Peppermint cups: around 38mg THC. Granola Bars ~36mg THC. Peanut Brittle Bar ~ STUNNING 71.46 mg THC. Sesame Brittle ~ 54.76 mg THC. Coconut Cups ~ 35.5 mg THC.

Industry Hint: Simply Pure has some big, big things planned for later this year – with not only better and more practical items on the menu, but smaller and more affordable versions of their original line.

item.title: Dixie Elixirs Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded: Elixirs: Once dubbed the more expensive, less effective version of Keef, Dixie Elixirs has come a long way from their hand-bottled days. Although some batches have been spotted with gritty residues at the top of bottles, the general consensus nowadays is that Dixie packs twice the punch of a regular Keef for a similar price (regardless what labels say), and is the better bang-for-buck. Their syrups are special-made out of Cali (including an original Sarsaparilla, whatever that tastes like). Their award winning Blueberry soda is winner among patients; orange tastes perhaps the least medicated. Between Peach, mandarin, and pomegranate, you wont likely be disappointed. Don’t drink until after cold.
