wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Gaias Garden, Granny Ts, Sweet Palliatives
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Gaia’s Garden
Zonkey Bar – The Zonkey bar does not sell that well. Its a combination of chocolate, almonds, cranberries, and pumpkin seeds, ultimately creating a questionable sweet taste in your mouth, and probably not enough to bring you back.
PB Blaster – The blaster works because its almost all medicated peanut butter. Essentially a fat, clump of Reeses, but better. That said, its difficult to not eat the whole thing in one fell swoop, especially with the little messiness. Then again, if youre not the kind of person who can easily down 2 Reeses cups consecutively–and especially if you cant handle a plain ol heaping spoonful of pure peanut butter alone–this will probably be too much.
Cloud 9 Bar and Balls – A dwarfed version of the larger and long-retired cloud 9 bars, these little guys pack a punch of THC and sugar. Nothing like chocolate, marshmallows, caramel, pretzels and coconut oil to invigorate the senses. Buy this when its on sale, for $3 or $4 bucks max.
Nookie Cookies - Two heart-shaped cookies. Kind of grainy and plain, but with a little hint of cranberry. Perfect for the vegan in your life.
Razzle Dazzle – The worst part of this bar is that it is white chocolate. White Chocolate lovers will love the white chocolate, but then youll have the problem of dosage compared to price. Gaias Gardens bars have almost always been known for their lower potency (Level 4 equals what, precisely?) and its that thick veil that seems to keep people from coming back. While this bar tastes good–dont buy it unless youre a white chocolate lover to start, and one with lower tolerance.
Almondeus, Milk & Dark – The almond glaze in the middle of the chocolate tastes okay, a moderate almond taste with a very moderate THC chocolate. Almondeus werent always Level 4 bars, to our best memory, but since becoming a Level 4, we havent felt any difference.
Harlequin Bar - Cayenne pepper infused chocolate sounds great, especially with a caramel center, but really isnt anything to write home about. The most annoying part of such an expensive bar, is the fact that you dont feel it very much either.
Rainbow Kaos Krunch - If you didnt think Fruity Pebbles could get any richer, encase a brick of the cereal in milk chocolate with coconut oil. Your tongue will hardly be able to handle the circus in your mouth. I didnt always feel the effects of this – so I gave it to another patient, a burly 230-pound guy whose tolerance was even higher than mine. He reported that it took him out for 10 hours, curiously enough. Another example of how edibles hit everyone differently.
CannaFish – Hard Candy fish in variety of flavors. Comes in 2x or 3x strengths – or at least, did – but not a very patient-appreciated candy line. Plays a second string to Dazys and most suckers. 

Granny Ts
Righteous Krispie Bar - This is not the most impressive cereal bar, but does involve a layer of chocolate. Not sure what else to say. Its a Rice Krispie bar with fairly moderate effect and a layer of freakin chocolate. Good luck fitting it in your mouth.
Peanut Brittle - Unlike other medible Peanut Brittle, often golden and loafed and gourmet-weird, Granny T presents the real thing, harkening to most holiday peanut brittles Ive ever seen. Its familiar. The problem is, how used to buying peanut brittle am I?
Lemon Bar - Definitely the hallmark of a Granny T edible, the Lemon bar looks like the exact replica of a Sunday-brunch-in-the-church-basement dessert, complete with the powdered sugar lining the meringue, and a perfectly powdery pastry crust.

OMG Peanut Butter Cookies – This is a no-brainer edible, a staple, a shelf-stuffer and patient-favorite. Thing is, the peanut butter cookie with Hershey kiss is the most important thing on a cookie platter, the first to go. And while Gaias Garden seemed to commit a bakers faux pas by inverting the chocolate kiss, the move hasnt permanently affected sales (although a pointy kiss seems to sell the cookie). In a retail atmosphere where brown does not sell well, this cookie somehow sells 2 or 3 at a time.

Zesty Crackers – These soup crackers dont have any effect whatsoever–unless youre the kind of person to eat a full bag of soup crackers. Assuming most patients will buy actual food before medicine, no one will be starving enough to try medicating in this absurdly wasteful fashion.

Kettle Chips – By far the worst selling item youll ever see on a dispensary shelf, these Kettle chips are over-salted, glycerin-dipped spuds, but at least have an undeniable effect (all that soaking in Canna-grease really pays off). As far as a shelf-life, these things will sit forever and ruin, simply due to their presentation. Theres a reason you dont buy cheese kettle crackers in a clear plastic bag–they look like the kind of thing Bruce Brodie would wipe his hands with to give a Mallrat diarrhea. Seriously, there is nothing appetizing about the sight of these chips, but if youre into couch-crashing with lots of beer on a Saturday afternoon, they may fit right in.
item.excerpt:encoded: Gaia’s Garden Zonkey Bar – The Zonkey bar does not sell that well. Its a combination of chocolate, almonds, cranberries, and pumpkin seeds, ultimately creating a questionable sweet taste in your mouth, and probably not enough to bring you back. … Continue reading →

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: How Cannapages Judges Edibles
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
The FIVE Ps
The Hallmark of a Staple Edible, to Cannapages.com:
A good edible doesnt require the whole package to be consumed. We typically insist on eating the whole package unless absolutely necessary, regardless. But a staple edible should not have a short shelf life. It should not require refrigeration, stirring, shaking, preparation, etc.
It should not be a food that consumers wont purchase on a normal basis. Goods that fly off the shelf at grocery stores or holiday party platters work the best. Word of mouth should precede the item (regarding its potency), and first glance should sell it.
That given, a staple edible cant be sold at a price that doesnt match the appearance, without proper explanation or hype. Potency must be explicitly portrayed on the label, especially for small objects. Otherwise, the edible should be very, very presentable, as to guise the hand-production (almost guaranteed at this stage in the industry). It should not be broken, leaking in any way, exposed whatsoever to light or air, smudged, too gooey or too dry. Packaging should be as clean-cut as possible; colors work best in the product and on the label; earth-tones always sell slower.
But most of all, a staple edible must be one that can be consumed day in and day out, or at least in rotation with a small handful of other staples. Whereas a person may not mind tossing a few slightly-offbeat culinary bits into their routine for medication purposes, they will not start directing their diet or snacking habits based on an edibles purchase. You cant expect to sell salsa, cornbread, or even ice cream on a regular basis, because a patient doesnt always carry chips with which to dip the salsa, or have a microwave to warm up todays bite of week-old corn bread, or have to access their ice cream in the freezer when theyre sitting in the library or on a bus. Customers who DO routinely buy one certain niche dietary item from their grocer, will probably find its medicated equivalent enticing at the dispensary. But even then, they may prefer the natural, non-canna version and depend on a completely different type of food or drink. Its not an easy thing to predict.
Ultimately, practicality, price, potency, presentation, and finally, palate, all go into an edibles potential to rise the ranks from generic to staple.

Granny Ts
Righteous Krispie Bar - This is not the most impressive cereal bar, but does involve a layer of chocolate. Not sure what else to say. Its a Rice Krispie bar with fairly moderate effect and a layer of freakin chocolate. Good luck fitting it in your mouth.
Peanut Brittle - Unlike other medible Peanut Brittle, often golden and loafed and gourmet-weird, Granny T presents the real thing, harkening to most holiday peanut brittles Ive ever seen. Its familiar. The problem is, how used to buying peanut brittle am I?
Lemon Bar - Definitely the hallmark of a Granny T edible, the Lemon bar looks like the exact replica of a Sunday-brunch-in-the-church-basement dessert, complete with the powdered sugar lining the meringue, and a perfectly powdery pastry crust.

OMG Peanut Butter Cookies – This is a no-brainer edible, a staple, a shelf-stuffer and patient-favorite. Thing is, the peanut butter cookie with Hershey kiss is the most important thing on a cookie platter, the first to go. And while Gaias Garden seemed to commit a bakers faux pas by inverting the chocolate kiss, the move hasnt permanently affected sales (although a pointy kiss seems to sell the cookie). In a retail atmosphere where brown does not sell well, this cookie somehow sells 2 or 3 at a time.

Zesty Crackers – These soup crackers dont have any effect whatsoever–unless youre the kind of person to eat a full bag of soup crackers. Assuming most patients will buy actual food before medicine, no one will be starving enough to try medicating in this absurdly wasteful fashion.

Kettle Chips – By far the worst selling item youll ever see on a dispensary shelf, these Kettle chips are over-salted, glycerin-dipped spuds, but at least have an undeniable effect (all that soaking in Canna-grease really pays off). As far as a shelf-life, these things will sit forever and ruin, simply due to their presentation. Theres a reason you dont buy cheese kettle crackers in a clear plastic bag–they look like the kind of thing Bruce Brodie would wipe his hands with to give a Mallrat diarrhea. Seriously, there is nothing appetizing about the sight of these chips, but if youre into couch-crashing with lots of beer on a Saturday afternoon, they may fit right in.
item.excerpt:encoded: Gaia’s Garden Zonkey Bar – The Zonkey bar does not sell that well. Its a combination of chocolate, almonds, cranberries, and pumpkin seeds, ultimately creating a questionable sweet taste in your mouth, and probably not enough to bring you back. … Continue reading →

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: How Cannapages Judges Edibles
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
The FIVE Ps
The Hallmark of a Staple Edible, to Cannapages.com:
A good edible doesnt require the whole package to be consumed. We typically insist on eating the whole package unless absolutely necessary, regardless. But a staple edible should not have a short shelf life. It should not require refrigeration, stirring, shaking, preparation, etc.
It should not be a food that consumers wont purchase on a normal basis. Goods that fly off the shelf at grocery stores or holiday party platters work the best. Word of mouth should precede the item (regarding its potency), and first glance should sell it.
That given, a staple edible cant be sold at a price that doesnt match the appearance, without proper explanation or hype. Potency must be explicitly portrayed on the label, especially for small objects. Otherwise, the edible should be very, very presentable, as to guise the hand-production (almost guaranteed at this stage in the industry). It should not be broken, leaking in any way, exposed whatsoever to light or air, smudged, too gooey or too dry. Packaging should be as clean-cut as possible; colors work best in the product and on the label; earth-tones always sell slower.
But most of all, a staple edible must be one that can be consumed day in and day out, or at least in rotation with a small handful of other staples. Whereas a person may not mind tossing a few slightly-offbeat culinary bits into their routine for medication purposes, they will not start directing their diet or snacking habits based on an edibles purchase. You cant expect to sell salsa, cornbread, or even ice cream on a regular basis, because a patient doesnt always carry chips with which to dip the salsa, or have a microwave to warm up todays bite of week-old corn bread, or have to access their ice cream in the freezer when theyre sitting in the library or on a bus. Customers who DO routinely buy one certain niche dietary item from their grocer, will probably find its medicated equivalent enticing at the dispensary. But even then, they may prefer the natural, non-canna version and depend on a completely different type of food or drink. Its not an easy thing to predict.
Ultimately, practicality, price, potency, presentation, and finally, palate, all go into an edibles potential to rise the ranks from generic to staple.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Benjamins Edibles Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Benilla Wafers: The Benilla Wafers make a good staple. Not to mention, a great improvement on an already great cookie, the vanilla wafer. Sandwiched together between two wafers, the green cannacream hits fairly hard and fast. Slight lemony taste to the cream; addictive and worth eating the whole bag. CannaStats: “100 mg THC” per bag (4 cookies at ~ 25mg each)
Ow-Wee-Ohs: Although the edges always seem to crack off, these large chocolate cookie sandwiches with their signature green Benjamin cream, are the decadent improvement on Oreos. Granted most oreo-based edibles simply consist of the original cookie encased in chocolate, but Benjamins wanted to actually reinvent it altogether. Each cookie sports 50 mg apiece, but only two come to a package. Good luck dosing with this one. CannaStats: “100 mg THC” per bag (2 cookies sandwiches)
Bank Rolls: Not necessarily an improvement on the Cheeba Chew potency, but at least with the taste. Of all the alternative versions of the Cheeba Chew, this one is far most requested. The biggest seller is the taste, more of an orange-based spice and cleaner tasting, without the sharp, pungent undertones associated with Cheebas. Toting 100mg, this seems a formidable opponent (especially for the same retail price, typically). The only things missing are the 3- or 5-pack versions (not to mention hybrid, indica, and sativa distinction). CannaStats: “100 Mg” per roll (compare to 70 mg Quad Dose Cheeba Chews)

Gum: Because its sloshing around your mouth capillaries for so long, this little guy gets right on top of you. It also tastes better than most other gums–but theres nothing to prevent it from losing all taste after 10 minutes. The question is: when is it okay to spit out gum that cost 3 bucks? Thankfully, with 50 mg distributed in a fat, large piece, youll have no problem dosing. Not a good method for night time medicating, though. Benjamin’s downfall was coming out with both 25 and 50 mg versions, which often overlap in pricing on the shelves and/or confuse customers and their bud-tenders.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Simply Pure Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Gourmet of the Gourmet: Peppermint Cups, Peanut Brittle, Coconut Almond Cups, Sesame Brittle and Granola Bars – phew. Simply Pure is certainly a shrugger as far as Edibles go, just like Whole Foods might be, for a hipster strapped for cash. On the one hand, theyre the brainchild of 8 Rivers Master Chef Scott Durrah and Mad Batter’s Lauren Gennett, and distributed by some of the coolest vendors in the industry. On the other hand, you can only sell $15 Peanut Brittle to a select crowd. The same with a granola bar, especially when the Buddha bar selling off the shelves at such a lower price. Granted, their gourmet chocolates really are gourmet, but even the most gourmet chocolates wont sell to people who dont buy them normally. One thing SP does well is presentation –good product packaging and photography . Then again, youll look at the sesame brittle and ask, Im paying $16 bucks for what? Dosaging: Be forewarned that you cant eat simply pure on an empty stomach–and the chocolates (especially the peppermint cups) are so rich that youll probably have to have something salty nearby to get it down. The record for dosing on this one was 3 packages on an empty stomach – to which the reviewer remarked,I dont know if I feel anything, do you?.

CannaStats: 100mg THC Per Package as advertised. Peppermint cups: around 38mg THC. Granola Bars ~36mg THC. Peanut Brittle Bar ~ STUNNING 71.46 mg THC. Sesame Brittle ~ 54.76 mg THC. Coconut Cups ~ 35.5 mg THC.

Industry Hint: Simply Pure has some big, big things planned for later this year – with not only better and more practical items on the menu, but smaller and more affordable versions of their original line.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Dixie Elixirs Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded: Elixirs: Once dubbed the more expensive, less effective version of Keef, Dixie Elixirs has come a long way from their hand-bottled days. Although some batches have been spotted with gritty residues at the top of bottles, the general consensus nowadays is that Dixie packs twice the punch of a regular Keef for a similar price (regardless what labels say), and is the better bang-for-buck. Their syrups are special-made out of Cali (including an original Sarsaparilla, whatever that tastes like). Their award winning Blueberry soda is winner among patients; orange tastes perhaps the least medicated. Between Peach, mandarin, and pomegranate, you wont likely be disappointed. Don’t drink until after cold.

item.title: Dazys Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Candies: Dazys flower-shaped candies were the first well-branded hard candies on the market, and to a certain degree, they still are. While they still make a rainbow of colorful varieties, including the best sugar-free version we know of, its been a while since they made a disctinction between certain potency levels for their candies. Not that it would make a difference. The candies have gone downhill since their inception, and patients arent asking for them anymore. Not to mention their cumbersome nature; like Willy Wonkas onscreen gobstoppers, you cant have a conversation, barely swallow juices, and pretty much have to bite the thing in half to keep from drooling on yourself. The price is still good – but not sure if these delicious candies still have the same allure they once did. Then again, there are those who swear by them. CannaStats: 100mg Cannabis Extract (CO2/H2O Extraction From 2.4g Strong Marijuana)

Caps:The best cap, hands down. An expensive one. Hits you hard the first time, the highest youve been in a long, long time. Not for the faint of heart, especially if eaten on an empty stomach. Even for those with high tolerances, the first time will hit you hard, starting with a gut-dropping sensation (free-fall, whether youve eaten or not) and grow into a hardcore high with riveting peaks, climaxing somewhere around hour 3-4 and then coming down accordingly. This, unlike so many other hash cap doses is only a pill for big medicators, and even then, only when you have time to be taken of out commission. CannaStats: 170mg Hash Oil (!)

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: CannaPunch
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Shades of CannaPunch

CannaPunch doesnt have much of a punch – and you can taste the glycerine. Bigger patients – burly guys for instance — have complained that they only feel the extreme CannaPunch versions, and only after drinking the entire bottle. The Fruit punch seemed the best pair for taste and cannabis, cloaking the canna-aftertaste best with the tart, familiar flavor profile of a generic Hawaiian Punch. The finish was smooth and dry, but not without a bad breath aftertaste. Some have called it rancid. For those who can overcome the tongue-curling, it doesnt make a bad addition to the cooler, but dont expect major effects from a few sips.

CannaStats: Makers of CannaPunch pride themselves on involving the tumor-fighting CBN (1.13mg) and 46.89 mg THC.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: The Buddha Bar Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
The Buddha Bar, Staple Edible

Presentation: Looks like a geriatic cow flopped into a package and sealed it. Thankfully, the Buddha Bar does not taste as green as it looks. Its a fairly run-of-the-mill granola bar with only slight flavor variations (you can barely taste the difference between Honey-Nut Berry and, say, Macademia Coconut). But the bar acheives a dizzying and/or heavy buzz. Very potent, most patients should begin with a nibble; technically the whole bar is almost equivalent to a Dazys Hash cap or Deca-Dose Cheeba Chew, and for a great price (obviously better when sold straight from vendor and not through middle-men).

Unlike other granola bars on the market, this one has a unique position to become an edibles staple, due mostly to potency. If nothing else, you should grab one of these for historic posterity and keep the wrapper. The crazy, feathered hippie girl behind Buddha (Gemma Star) is on her way skyward, in so many ways.

Dosage: Entire bar contains ~ 150mg THC

item.title: Dr. Js Hash Infusion Edibles Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Dr. J's Hash Infusion Edibles

Products: Buzz Buttons (Chocolate Brownies), Magic Lemon Poppyseed Muffins, Chocolate-Chip ‘Kosmic’ Cookies (with muffin version).

Finally, its time for a review on the much-hyped Hash Infusion products from Dr. Js kitchen. Almost overnight, Dr. Js sprung up on shelves all over the state, with one claim: the baked goods were literally 250mg hash in an air-tight package! Many dispensary owners agreed to carry the products without even sampling them. Who could disagree with the dosage, compared to the price? The Dr. Js team claimed they had the product of the year, because the hash infusion was “so much stronger,” and that one serving would “blow the Cheeba Chew away.” Their exact claim, per package, is 125mg of hash per serving.

Dr. Js makes muffins, cookies and brownies. All were, unfortunately, rather disappointing. After eating an entire package, I felt a mild headbuzz for fifteen minutes, and then nothing. A girl with a smaller frame reported eating just one serving of the brownies and feeling effects for hours – but only after smoking more and drinking a little. Another cannasseur noted that he experienced a subtle acrid undertone, and that he felt nothing from the Hash Infusion. The taste was okay–both brownies and cookies crumbled into a million dry pieces, and the muffins didn’t impress.

Actual Package Dosage Verbiage: 250 mg of Concentrated Trichome Extract per package.
item.excerpt:encoded: The taste was okay--both brownies and cookies crumbled into a million dry pieces, and the muffins didn't impress. Continue reading →

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CannaCritiques - Medical Marijuana Product & Business Reviews from the people of Cannapages.com

item.title: Cheeba Chews Quad Dose Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Cheeba Chews started off with two products: a 2x dosage and a 4x dosage (the Quad). Over time, demand for the more potent product far outweighed that for the 2x, and Cheeba Chews became renowned for their undeniable effect, even for those who didn’t often try edibles. The MMJ tootsie rolls are still produced in quad dose (and deca) and available in three types: Sativa, Indica and Hybrid.

Cheeba Chews Quad Dose

Sativa – The best-selling Cheeba Chew by far. Some buy them by the fist-full. Sativa Cheeba Chews probably produce one of the most consistent psychedelic highs associated with edibles of any sort, and the patients have spoken. Its one thing when a client returns for the same edible a week later. But when they insist on weekly visits for 10+ of any product, you know you have an industry standard on your shelves.

Indica – The black label puts you out, of course. For someone with a higher tolerance, you may not feel much, except the desire to sleep. However, someone who smokes only once a day, the chew may cause instant “burn-out” if taken to early. Seasoned smokers have suggested that a chew is appropriate. 1st timers should try about bite no earlier than mid-afternoon, and progress from there.

Hybrids – Hybrids are most reported to have the headaches associated with Cheeba Chews purged but signature BHO taste. Cigarette smokers, however, did not report any headaches. In fact, for the 10% of the population that prefers the hybrid–they always buy the hybrid, for its combination of chill-out pain relief with heady-focus.
item.excerpt:encoded: Sativa Cheeba Chews probably produce one of the most consistent psychedelic highs associated with edibles of any sort, and the patients have spoken. Continue reading →

item.title: OrganaLabs CannaTabs and AtmosRx Reviewed
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
First, let it be said that OrganaLabs leads the way in both technology and product presentation, blowing the market away first with their MedaVape, then Atmos Vaporizer, and now their pure hash oil (it’s already used in Apothecanna’s “Supper Salve” production). The CannaCritics agree that while the products don’t always work as well as they could–at least they’re different.

CannaTabs from OrganaLabs

CannaTabs – The CannaTabs supposedly work best when left to dissolve, one at a time, under your tongue. This works for the most part, except for the grainy feeling you just cant shake, even after its gone. These caps are a good buy, 3 for probably $10-12 retail, but cant really tell if they do much or not. Initial high is center-of-the-head, extending straight down the very middle of the body like a pole. The most unbearable part of these – assuming youre sucking on the thing until dissolves completely–is the fact that its almost as bad a sucking on a factory-made pill that has been designed to disguise the taste. In this case, the medicinal taste cant be hidden, and the result is what tastes like a pure sugar-cube, ultimately sweet, but without enough tartness to escape the otherwise planty/medicinal side. The plus side, however, is that the medicine goes straight into your bloodstream instead of digesting–and–unlike normal hash caps, these are vitamin-esque, hard little pills that wont leak or lose as much potency on the shelf.

The AtmosRx Vaporizer from OrganaLabs

AtmosRx Vape- the AtmosRx Vaporizer is a larger version of the first little tech-piece on the market, the MedaVape. Unlike the the MedaVape, AtmosRx packs an undeniable and strong hit for at least the first 30 puffs. Those used to getting a smoky-return from their vape will be somewhat taken aback by this smokeless apparatus, but quickly won over by its redeeming charms. For one, the stronger battery heats the element better – apparently at the correct optimum heat – instead of creating a petty little charge that does little for effect. Second, the cartridge, although not much more expensive on the shelves, is twice the quantity of hash oil of the MedaVape equivalent (at least–unless you got the 200mg cartridge AtmosRx, and then kudos to you). Third, OrganaLabs is set to release a full line of flavored cartridges in the next few months, making this experience almost like the tincture/eCigarette phenomenon, only potent. Comes with both USB charger, and a wall charger to plug USB chargers into. Literally, they thought of everything. The only drawback to vaping this style at any time, is that cannabis, in its most pure and vaped version, seems to take on the New Book Smell, and suckling this smoke-free apparatus can feel like smooching a new best-seller.

Note to those using this kind of vaporizer: dont let your vaporizer stand up for very long, or youll have to store it upside-down to get the hash oil back towards the mouthpiece. Due to the amount of vegetable glycerin required to get the right viscosity–its insoluble with the hash oil–the apparatus does have the tendency to clog if not used often, and is best stored in different positions daily to keep the two ingredients as mixed as much as possible. Otherwise, most people report that AtmosRx will impress for the first 20-30 hits per cartridge, and then start to decline slowly for another 100 puffs or so.

Price: These can get expensive, starting around $85-$95 retail.
item.excerpt:encoded: Due to the amount of vegetable glycerin required to get the right viscosity--its insoluble with the hash oil--the apparatus does have the tendency to clog if not used often... Continue reading →

item.title: LSD from The Green House
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: LSD

Dispensary: The Green House

LSD is a another love-child of Skunk #1, this time mixed with Mazar for a sparkling, musky indica with euphoric effects. The Green House produces their own emerald version, with nearly white hairs and healthy plump calyxes like little morsels. Emanating from the container–and throughout the house–came the reek of a signature skunk, like a donut or frosting, which turned into an aroma of ice cream when ground. The taste was more chemical, and reminded the CannaCritics of nag champa.

The effects of LSD Cannabis don’t exactly match the psychedelic acid by the same moniker. But it hits strong, especially initially. Lips tingling, eyes watering, the high came on quickly, piercing through the body from center of the head right now to the feet within 2 minutes. One hit was good enough for anyone with low tolerance. Its cannabinoid profile seemed best received when smoked through a steamroller. High creative sessions ensued, and the strain was good for either day or night–just not all day long. When smoked at night, the effects carried through until morning, when a hangover-like fogginess lingered.

One full bowl was more than enough for a full-time medicator; critics with the strongest tolerance would find a 1/2 to full bowl adequate for functional high. Given its taste, LSD would be perfect in edibles, especially ice creams and fruit-based confections. After 2.5 hours, the cerebral effects had worn off, leaving behind the indica properties to casually alleviate pain and raging nerves.

Type: Mostly Indica

Testing: 18.90% Total Cannabinoids – See Full Results from Herbal Synergy
item.excerpt:encoded: LSD is a another love-child of Skunk #1, this time mixed with Mazar for a sparkling, musky indica with euphoric effects. The Green House produces their own emerald version, with nearly white hairs and healthy plump calyxes like little morsels. Continue reading →

item.title: Crimson Tide from Herbal Options
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Crimson Tide

Dispensary: Herbal Options

There’s not much literature written about the elusive Crimson Tide strain…it has a good chance of either coming from Alabama, or at least paying homage to a natural phenomenon involving algae. There’s nothing ‘crimson’ about the actual bud that we can tell (at least, from the sample provided by Herbal Options), unless by crimson, they mean, mother of pearl. Sugary and slightly citrus, these well-packed nugs electrify the senses like a classic Flo or Obama.

Unlike a creeping undertow, Crimson Tide slams powerfully, and continues in rippling aftershocks for the first several minutes. Expect to be hit double-hard on an empty stomach. For 20-70 seconds, the brain reels in numb shock, followed by waves crashing against shoulders, and them arms. Nerves danced at the roof of the mouth and tips of the fingers. For nearly three hours, at least two seasoned critics were floored. One had to concentrate when walking. Not everyone wants to turn into the Minister of Silly Walks when they medicate, but with proper preparation and circumstances, it can be quite pleasant. Note that there was no ‘floating’ involved. Simply a dumbfounded brain-stem losing its rhythm.

The Tide did make exposure to the sun more tolerable, adding to another reason this will make for a great beach strain. Peon duties, such as shoveling and dishes, were not as dull and boring, but mistakes were made. Wait an hour to do something responsible, and avoid social dialogue for the first 15-30 minutes. After that initial half-hour, the uncontrollable mind-warp settles down into a long-lasting vibrations throughout the body. The whole thing ended in a deep relaxation that may exhaust some (one critic fell asleep at his desk before 5PM). The whole team found it an ideal summer afternoon smoke for well-deserving citizens performing hard and repetitive physical work. Concentration may be required.

Profile: Classified as Indica by Herbal Options

Testing: 14.99% Total Cannabinoids. See full test results from Herbal Synergy.
item.excerpt:encoded: There's not much out there on the elusive Crimson Tide...the strain has a good chance of either coming from Alabama, or at least paying homage to a natural phenomenon involving algae....Unlike a creeping undertow, Crimson Tide slams with powerful initial waves, and continues into rippling aftershocks for the first several minutes Continue reading →

item.title: Super Lemon Haze from Natures Way
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Super Lemon Haze (SLH)

Dispensary: Nature’s Way

With classic SLH, Super Silver Haze and Lemon Skunk are unified in a mind-blowing, THC whirlwind of a hard-hitting sativa. The specimen provided by Nature’s Way tickled the nose like a renegade moustache and brought out sneezing and red eyes even before getting into the bowl. That’s when you realize how much taste is part of the high. Lemon is an obvious taste, as well as the many other citruses and creamy aromas that come with a heritage of intertwined skunks and haze varieties.

This Haze was full-on cerebral ringing, 100% face-grabbing, with stellar increase in effects for the 1st hour. Emotional equilibrium was reached, harmony with nature and all that jazz, rippling into waves of creativity and spastic double-takes due to electric senses. Small things became quick distractions but everything existed in a peaceful state. Must be the tiny sparks of Northern Lights and Citral surfacing from deep within the genetics.

The rest, however, is all sativa. A great athletic strain, the most powerful haziness set in for an hour. The second hour ensued with beads of pain-alleviating numbness trickling through the body. Heavy forgetfulness and lack of focus were noted and forgotten. But each period of head-in-the-sky daydreaming swung back into heavy focus and drive. Hiking, biking, or catching a good flick at night would all be greatly enhanced. Those with low tolerances may find operating machinery extremely difficult; those with sensitivity to sativas will go absolutely goat-herding mad with panic. Slight munchies were successfully treated with carrots.

Profile: Mostly Sativa

Testing: 16.65% Total Cannabinoids.

See full results from Herbal Synergy.
item.excerpt:encoded: Strain: Super Lemon Haze (SLH) Dispensary: Nature’s Way With classic SLH, Super Silver Haze and Lemon Skunk are unified in a mind-blowing, THC whirlwind of a hard-hitting sativa. The specimen provided by Nature’s Way tickled the nose like a renegade … Continue reading →

item.title: Trainwreck from Dank LLC
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Trainwreck

Dispensary: Dank, LLC

For those of us who really enjoy our medical marijuana, running into a cannabis nerd can be sort of a downer, especially when that person has ever graced the vicinity of Humboldt County, or, God forbid, lived there. Certainly, no such connoisseur will let a Trainwreck spliff pass by without expunging a local history upon willing ears nearby, how it’s a clone-only protege from the Emerald Triangle, how tall it grew in their back yard garden, etc. The only consolation is that Trainwreck is known for pulverizing the senses while energizing the body, all great side-effects for when you’re getting lectured by professor McCannaGeek.

The CannaCritics grabbed a handful from Dank LLC and went about testing, making sure that no such historians were in the room. The strain’s buds were tight but with pleasurable crumble into the bowl; amber crystals showed perfect timing on the harvest. Pine and vanilla hit the palate along with other fruity sensations of sultry creaminess; it was the bowl that seemed to keep giving, hit and after hit. We found the best wreckage was achieved with a deep one-hitter, three puffs, each 10 minutes apart. Each lung-full was ghosted for maximum effect.

Trainwreck’s first assault was medium to strong. But there was no fogginess or reeling. Heavyset brow-buzz struck above the eyes and then appeared tumbling down the back of the legs. Despite the fragmented bursts of energy coursing through the nerves, the critics dabbled with slight loss of focus, in vision, as well as organization and problem-solving. By the third puff creativity was blooming, not to a psychedelic dysfunctional effect, but rather in inspiring self-awareness and attention to manifesting metaphors.

Jamming on a Friday night would make for a great Trainwreck activity; it’s a great pairing for anyone burning the midnight oil. Don’t, however, offer it to any philosophical ramblers. Munchies were not an issue; subtle hunger was out-panged by thirst for coke or Gatorade; a citrus gum did just the trick.

Two well-known Trainwreck seed companies breed Afghani and Mexican with either Columbia or Thai. Dank seems to have the Columbia version, a medium-strong sativa that lasts about 2 hours. No matter what the potency or heritage, at least the Humboldt proud-can be sure of its dependability.

Profile: Mostly Sativa

Testing: 14.0% Total Cannabinoids.

item.title: Afghani-Skunk from The Green House
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Afghani Skunk

Dispensary: The Green House

Bringing out the Afghanistan roots in native Skunk, this marriage with Afghani (100% indica) creates a CBD-heavy strain that has strong psychedelic characteristics. In other words, it’s the perfect thing for getting locked to the couch and staring at the mushroom-munching gnome in a blacklight poster, for hours at a time.

The bud itself was dark and ominous, flat and unpredictable. The flower did not glisten. Hairs ranged from a red almond to even chocolate color; the critics noted a great cure but a mediocre trim. Still, the rich skunk overpowered the resinous undertones of a middle-eastern hashish staple, and sweetened with a good grinding.

Thick smoke billowed with every puff, as if full of ash. Initial waves were unconvincing, mild and sometimes un-affecting, until the full power of a creeping sensation was realized at or after 10 minutes. Even that epiphany carried impact, as at least three CannaCritics agreed what it felt like: a hand entering the spine from behind and continuing up the neck and into the face, as if they were becoming puppets. By that time, the feet were tingling along with select spots in-between. The relaxation took on a floating effect after about 25 minutes. It was immediately deemed perfect for conversation and good times with good friends.

After 2 hours of the strongest effects, followed the lingering heaviness in the the eyes and neck. Psychedelic as it was initially, the creeping sensations found an appropriate place to climax and settle back down. But not until after undergoing a roller-coaster of nearly-impairing body buzzes, rotating among high climbs of THC craziness. Habitual smoking of the strain may put stress on relationships or conversations with acquaintances or colleagues; it must be medicated in the correct atmosphere with the right people. Don’t consume multiple bowls throughout the day; save it for the poker game or barbecue on the patio.

Music performance or jamming at night was easier and cohesive. Dumb humor was funny (such as South Park) and munchies were light (treated with a couple of Oreos).

Profile: Grower-Declared Sativa, CannaCritics go with Sativa-dominant Hybrid

Testing: 16.92% Total Cannabinoids

In other words, it’s the perfect thing for getting locked … Continue reading →

item.title: Diesel from The Green House
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Diesel

Dispensary: Green House

Often in our quests for the most exotic strain for special occasions, we overlook the everyday staple strains that once were revered as legends. One of those particular staples is Diesel, the Critics pick for best appetizer-bowl before a great feast. Sour, musky, and dark, this high-grade energy bud can be found in a variety of phenotypes grown throughout U.S. Although probably not the Original Diesel, (Chem Dawg – based), our sample from The Green House resonated with the signature Diesel taste and revealed both Mexican and Afghani roots in aroma.

The dosage for this review was actually set at .5 grams for each critic, regardless of tolerance. It came out to about a bowl and a half–which was more than ample, especially for those smoking for the first time that day. Those with lower tolerances barely made it through the sample; they were floored. Strong tugging sensations appeared behind the eyes and throughout the back of the head; cottonmouth ensued for a short period. The body high crept along as the daze deepened, and staring into space became commonplace. One particular critic left to get a breath of fresh air and didnt return until 45 minutes later, apparently in the midst of a philosophical battle with himself.

Extremely potent and well-cured, the bud burned well and lasted long. For an average two hours and fifteen minutes, the high carried several critics through great social interaction and music appreciation or performance. Everyone agreed that it would be more appropriate for late afternoon or early evening, especially with good friends right before supper. Two chronic pain-sufferers noted reduction in both bad headache and tense nerves.

At an hour and a half, the effects began to mellow for high tolerance patients. However, one of our biggest, a 64 fella at 200 lbs, was fully medicated for 2.5 hours. Still uplifting at the finish line, we were in good moods as we left the office, content, but not mind-sore or burnt out.

Profile: Sativa (Critics assume a 65/35 S/I split)

Testing: 15.06% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Death Star from Herbal Options
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Death Star

Dispensary: Herbal Options

The Death Star may culturally be as old Generation X, but the strain surfaced just after the turn of the millennium. Named for the intergalactic synthetic planet of Vader and his Troopers, the strain is well known for its sensational strong indica effects, with unusually high THC. Thats thanks to its Sensi Star heritage, crossed with the dominating cerebral versatility of the Sour Diesel.

The specimen from Herbal Options was beautiful with hints of purple. A pinch and grind revealed strong aroma, like that of an early 80s wood paneling. The first taste was heavily skunk-based, tropical and surprising. The longer it burned, more of a California plum emerged from the palate, even sweet like tobacco or a flowers nectar.

Interestingly enough, the high was not immediately staggering. Favoring the left side, both a head and body sensation erupted at the back of the neck, continued through the shoulders and then crossing over. There was no sky-walking. The eyes fuzzed a little and senses came in tune but there were no mind tricks. No floating. Even after 20 minutes, it was a very manageable, work-friendly high.

Sooner than later, organization was lost; physical work was still possible but administrative tasks became impossible. The full body fuzz was good for all-day relief–but those with low tolerances will become burnt out and sleep through most of it. All in all, a great stoner-fogginess set in, leaving everything slower and less interesting. The skin continued to tingle and the nerves chilled with numbness, especially along the spine. After 2.5 hours, effects faded, with the team having collectively accomplished very little.

Great for music, philosophy, or getting to know someone, this strain is bad for changing the world. Or, universe, depending on your scopes.

Profile: Indica

Testing: 21.64% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Northern Lights from Herbal Options
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Northern Lights

Dispensary: Herbal Options

Northern Lights has such a notable psychedelic effect because the actual true strain was introduced in clone form. Rather than pair it with another Afghani, seeds were derived using a sativa, probably Skunk #1 or Original Haze (the CannaCritics’ theory, based on palate, is Skunk #1). Creamy and smooth, the strain is well-known for a lazy effect coupled with mind-bending awareness. From Herbal Options came a dense specimen covered in nonchalant orange hairs, but less crystals than expected. The aroma had subtle traces of oak, with a “dry” skunk pungency. Harsh and heavy, there was little flare in the smoke, except for a resinous aftertaste.

The first of two large hits from a glass bowl struck the neck first and flung into the hands. In minutes they had numbed slightly. Through the muscles lingered an uncoiling buzz, somewhere between mild and medium potency. Lethargy was a main side effect, but the brain was still functioning at 90%, and there was no major alleviation of pain. By the second puff, awareness and visuals set in, but without significant impairment of motor skills. Also somewhat surprising was the brevity of the sensations, lasting no longer than an hour and a half.

Good for relaxation, Northern Lights can kill motivation in its tracks, and is awful for finishing projects. That said, it makes the perfect elixir vitae for long-distance road trips in the back seat, or even just lazy picnics during sunset. Given the shorter duration, it is ideal for events; space-out may ensue but not without promise of definitive end. Finally, medicating seemed to rescind hunger a little, and even small doses could help as a diet-regulator before meals.

Profile: 70% Indica

Testing: 16.64% Total Cannabinoids.

item.title: Tangerine Dream from Natures Way
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Tangerine Dream

Dispensary: Nature’s Way

This Tangerine Dream was so stemmy, that only its flowery aroma and crystalline surface saved the appearance. Citrus at times, the smell and taste were mostly resinous and harsh when broken apart and smoked. It was a slight disappointment as far as presentation goes, in general. A cross of A5 Haze and G13, us Critics love the Tang-Dream best when it actually smells like Tang, and flattens the smoker with unusually high CBD.

The 1st hit riveted down the spine, with tension in the lower back subsiding within seconds. Focus remained intact at for the next 10 minutes; a relaxing high blossomed from the back of the neck and extended through the arms, but very slowly. After a half-hour, the entire weight of the buzz had set in. Some activities, such as showering and bike repair, became difficult. Organization lagged. One pile of papers quickly became 10, and then 20–and at that point, projects were put off until after the effects had worn off (for fear of making too many mistakes). Muscles turned to jelly and the mind began wandering lucidly.

Seasoned veterans will probably get a good 1.5-2 hours from this strain, a consistently solid head high accompanied by notable torso relief. Functionality is not entirely crippled, and patients may be able to do simpler activities, such as biking, sewing, playing with the grandkids, etc. Those with lower tolerances will find their faces–lips and forehead in particular–tingling extraordinarily, and may have trouble with social dialogue for the first 15-30 minutes.

Definite munchies and thirst were realized and taken care of about 45 minutes into the effects.

Profile: Grower-declared Indica, Critics give it at least a 65% Sativa split.

Testing: 13.15% Total Cannabinoids

Citrus at times, the smell and taste were mostly resinous and harsh when broken apart and smoked. … Continue reading →

item.title: Orange Bud from Dank LLC
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Orange Bud
Dispensary: Dank LLC

As Cannasseurs know, Skunk #1s bizarre mutations and breeding have led to a vast family tree that tastes and smells like cheese on one end of the spectrum, and citrus or cream on another. One of the mutations, Orange Bud, leans more towards the fruity–prevalent are light tones of plum, peach, grapefruit, and more. Care should be taken to enjoy the palate like one would savor the changing leaves of Autumn.

The woody smoke reveals even more spices and sours from the bud, which came to the CannaCritics from Dank LLC with thick calyxes and vibrant orange pistils. The effect came on strongly; there was only slightly more body buzz than psychedelia, make this hybrid split down the middle. The dose–3 hits from glass–was energizing for the first hour. Thought-provoking, the mind raced, but with just enough indica to keep the jitters away. Meditative self-analyzing turned philosophical and relaxing. A soothing chill swept across the nerves about an hour in, and limbs became heavy.

Concentration was never a huge issue with Orange Bud; after a few minutes of fogginess, focus returned, making the Orange a great study-buddy or movie date. After 2.5-3 hours, the whole high had passed through. Never head-pounding, this medium-spicy dish only teased the tongue with a hint of psychedelia without pushing medicators beyond the looking glass. Descent from the high was an uneventful landing; a chill set in, and every delicate touch became a pin-prick until the sensations faded.

Munchies developed for 30-50 minutes, and then Jimmy Johns delivered. Exercising was amplified for those first 45 minutes energy-wise, but died down considerably thereafter.

Profile: For those who need a damn-near 50/50 hybrid, this one walks the line.

Testing: 13.17% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Cherry Lime from The Green House
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Cherry Hash

Dispensary: Green House

Not much is published on Cherry Hash, and its lineage is disputed; its a mix, possibly with a Hash Plant or Cherry Bomb. The sample supplied by The Green House was thick and hearty with strong, square nodes. There were a couple too many extra leaves, but at least they were full of crystals. Anticipating a scent to match its moniker, we were satisfied to get the rustic cherry smell coupled with orange. There emerged a cherry sour tone when smoked, with pine and nuts, but nothing overpowering.

What the CL produced was a laughing, happy high. There was body relief too–but less indica than expected. It crept in quietly. Senses were more alert and studying/reading was still possible. An energy kick was present at first, but faded by the first hour. Munchies developed and the tastebuds were working at 110%. Everything became somewhat chaotic–but settled down as the sensations reached the extremities. When all was said and done, the mind wasn’t blown, the rattled nerves weren’t completely soothed–but a nice balance struck between the two.

A brief strain, the effects faded in under 2 hours, lingering through the fingertips for another 30 minutes. The taste is excellent when cured and grown with the right nutrients. For a classic “indica,” the Critics think Cherry Lime makes a better afternoon “hybrid” for when you’re cleaning the “garage” and also drinking “beer.” Certainly not dependable for sleep, it may help produce a focused thesis over the weekend, or pair wonderfully with athletic endeavors. The Critics found that Cherry Lime makes a good “plain” candidate to base an exotic strain repertoire around, sort of like the coffee you make at home, versus the Venti Raspberry No-Whip Mocha you buy after lunch.

Profile: Grower-declared Sativa, (Critics say 55/45 Sativa Hybrid)

Testing: 11.29% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Chem 9 from Herbal Options
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Chem 9

Dispensary: Herbal Options

What may be a puzzling saga to some, the underground relationship between legendary breeders Chemdog and Joebrand has produced a new and steady stream of the popular Chemdawg variations in the last decade or so. Remarkably, this year marks a 20th anniversary of the fateful Grateful Dead concert that united the two. Not even 5 years ago, the two collaborated to produce phenotypes like Chem 4 (Joebrand claimed nostalgically that it was nearly identical to the ’91 bud) and others from the original seeds. But tracking the phenotypes has gotten a little out of hand, and there’s little telling on the medtender’s shelf whether your Chem is the original, or #4, or #9, or whatever few survived. What’s known of the #9 is that it can be more uplifting, and that the taste and smell is sweeter than other Chems.

And sweet it was, or at least our specimen from Herbal Options, which spread across the palate like a green tea or mocha. The spice was reminiscent of chai and reminded one critic of a fortune cookie, with hints of rose lacing the sugary aftertaste. Even better were the first shockwaves ripping across the brain. It was a head-turner and knee-jerker, even for high-tolerance critics. Euphoric bursts rose to the top of the head, starting from the torso. There was noticeable pain alleviation throughout the upper body, but not without a bittersweet loss of a some motor skills. Writing, in particular, was difficult for the first 30 minutes. Munchies were minimal.

The beautiful thing about this Chem was a great portrait of body, with layers of psychedelic spatial distortion high. For those with acute upper body issues–such as back pain or carpal tunnel–the Chem 9 makes a great “wake-and-bake” for relief until lunch (assuming there’s a coffee pot nearby). And with less clarity than classic Chemdawg, #9 is an ideal weekend variation, great for relaxed mornings, cleaning and yardwork.

Profile: Indica

Testing: 12.87% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Exodus Cheese from Natures Way
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Exodus Cheese

Dispensary: Nature’s Way

Many Cheese strains cross with Afghani or Kush to create hard-hitting narcotic indica effects. But few realize that Cheese, in its original form, was a clone-only lineage derived from an original Skunk #1. Born in the late 80′s, a Cheese mother eventually made her way into Exodus, a hippie commune in England, by the mid-90′s. There, its flavors were refined to enhance the classic musty essence locked within Skunk #1′s Afghani genetics. Also, it may have been distributed to every hippie from Dunstable to Winch Hill, for a good decade or more.

Although it’s difficult to find an unaltered version of the original, seeds became available–usually crossed with 100% indicas–around when Tony Blair took office. The real strain is still musky and earthy as ever, displaying the affinage of a creamy Skunk bred for pungency. The specimen from Nature’s Way did not disappoint in terms of nose-turning sweetness; in fact, after careful consideration, the critics decided its stink was that of an aged Irish Cheddar.

Hits were taken from a large water pipe. Immediately, a pinching, nervous sensation grabbed the jowls, into the cheeks, circling ’round the head and eyes. Cloudiness settled immediately over conscious thought and attention was lost repeatedly. The brainstem was functioning at full capacity, though, and grooving to beats felt natural, therapeutic. The creeping body effects fooled critics as playfully mild at first, but within a half-hour everyone felt the rousing Exodus in full form, throughout the extremities.

Philosophical and moving, the E.C. made for a great grocery-shopping strain, or any thought processes involving checklists and plans. Decision-making and judgement were impaired, as was wit, in general. Not great for being in the spotlight, avoid making speeches or directing choir with this one. Also a second-guesser, one would have a miserable time showering, cooking, or with any activities where severe short-term memory loss would be time-consuming and costly.

With an 8 out of 10 for potency, Exodus Cheese is a great veteran’s pick for dependable relief. Critics experienced an average 2-hour high, with effects receding after 1.5 hours and lingering as long as 3 hours. Munchies were not noted whatsoever…however, a cheese-plate full of Dubliner, Kerrygold and other imports, seems appropriate.

Profile: Hybrid Effects (Skunk #1 derivative)

Testing: 14.30% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Power Kush from Dank LLC
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Power Kush

Dispensary: Dank LLC

The Power Kush mother plant which reportedly is responsible for all pure Power Kush strainsis the in-bred child of a two hybrids from the same parents: 100% Indica (Afghani is assumed) crossed with Skunk #1. That makes it a daring cerebral strain whose effects tend toward a Hindu Kush. How it got its moniker is a mystery, although it seems to be an official “psychedelic” version of Northern Lights.

It arrived at Cannapages Headquarters in a small plastic bag which erupted with resinous smell, as well as strawberry and orange notes. Even more appealing was its sugary pumpkin-donut smell when broken apart (it kept the roasted pastry smell through the smoke, pleasantly enough). No doubt it would make the perfect strain for a baker’s delicacies, like medicated pies and Canna-Canals.

Power Kush exhibited the effects of a mild stimulant, powering and hammering both the head and arms. A strong Skunk cerebral high surfaced first, although the overall potency was suitable enough for working and concentration. Not too cloudy, a full-body buzz grew as the mind-warping effects wore off. It wasn’t the kind of high one enjoys at concerts or on camping trips–but was appropriate for everyday tasks and problem-solving. Creativity climaxed after about 45 minutes, and the ending wrought on a back-and-forth drowsiness that wouldn’t make it a good morning-to-noon selection.

After 1.5 hits from a large water pipe, most critics said the effects lasted strongly for 1 hour, then reduced to a simmering body buzz for another 1-2 hours. Munchies were minimal and treated with oreos and granola bars.

Profile: Indica Dominant Hybrid (CannaCritics give it a 65/35 I/S Split)

Testing: 14.70% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Urkle from Alternative Medicine on Capitol Hill (AMCH)
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Urkle

Dispensary: Alternative Medicine on Capitol Hill (AMCH)

A glistening mutant of the Purps genotype, Urkle is some of the most exotic looking bud youll find. la Mardi Gras, the bright green calyxes, orange pistils, and dark purple leaves create an a beautiful and colorful spectacle that naturally signals festive times. The personal cure added a hint of woodiness to the overall aroma from our AMCH specimen, but the taste was definitive grape. Not the fruit itself, or even jelly, per se, but clear and utter grape SweetTart. The large, silver-dollar sized grape SweetTart.

We were bedazzled from the start. The bud was best packed and smoked when ground-up, and similar to pressing a fresh, milky sugar cube into millions of tiny crystals, with bursts of subtle citrus/Tang filling the air. It burned smoothly, with pure white ash in the bowl and almost no smoke upon exhale. Just like velvet.

The first puff yielded subtle sinking sensations in the palms, spine and posterior. Tingling began at the back of the head but no extraordinary mind-numbing was noted just yet. The second puff was held in for stronger effect, which brought out a luscious Pinot Noir after-taste. Immediately, new and exciting effects hit throughout the body. Pressure points were most affected, and seemed to ring with soothing waves. No one complained of cerebral impairment, but it was obvious that the high was creeping into the head, starting with muscles in the torso.

Urkle is a great body strain that focuses on relaxation, but it will cause heaviness and lethargy throughout the nervous system. It made concentration possible, but also demanded a comfortable chair and short task list. Ideal for attending baseball games or a post-dinner puff, the strain also offered a sort of numbness to negative environmental stimuli like loud noises and hot temperatures. Taken after 8pm, however, expect to start searching for a pillow. Some of the smaller-framed critics were exhausted at only 50 minutes in, when the head rush was at its climax.

Sublime pacification in delicious form, Urkles high potency only caused one adverse side effect, which was a tendency to feel bubbles forming in the back of the throat, generating a sort of compulsory need to swallow for a few (even for patients with high tolerance). With a solid 17.85% THC, it’s just another reason to plan on dosing carefully with the Urkle.

Profile: Indica (Critics give it a 75/25 I/S Split, perhaps 70/30)

Testing: 18.07% Total Cannabinoids

item.excerpt:encoded: Pressure points were most affected, and seemed to ring with soothing waves. No one complained of cerebral impairment, but it was obvious that the high was creeping into the head, starting with muscles in the torso. Continue reading →

item.title: Camelot Kush from Natures Way
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Camelot Kush

Dispensary: Nature’s Way

The Camelot Kush answers a sort of theoretical question, which is: if Jack Herer had grown a Kush, what would it have been like? Strong and noble? Stealthy and psychedelic? Turns out the strain is mellow and calming, nowhere close to the cerebral intensity of Princess, as Camelot‘s C99 essences are often trumped by the straight indica hand of its other parent, Bubba Kush.

Heavily resinous when ground, the dense buds from Nature’s Way were covered in red hairs and tints of purple, suggesting velvet Pakistani undertones. But there was little actual taste from the smoke, surprising given the kief covering its dark surface. That said, there was also very little unpleasant aftertaste.

While cotton-mouth was almost immediately present, there was nothing executive about the strain, nor melodramatic. A creeping buzz turned into more of a stony head high, not as strong as expected, but turning the eyes completely red. The foggy effect left a few critics fumbling over words. Steadily, the buzz lasted for over an hour, with the first major waves balancing out after about a half hour. The body continued to linger, but in subtle tides like an aspirin.

Sleepy towards the end (head first, followed by body) those with stronger tolerances may have to take 5 hits to feel the full effects–and could then fall asleep at the climax. Those with lower tolerances felt it for the full 2 hours. Awkward for social settings, it was deemed best for weekends away from people and destinations. Devoid of any munchies, the strain made for a light buzz with a hard crash toward the end; be ready for a nap.

Profile: Indica Dominant Hybrid (Critics give it 75/25 I/S Split)

Testing: 16.12% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: C99 from Altitude Organic Medicine
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: C99

Dispensary: Altitude Organic Medicine in Colorado Springs

If Princess is the Haze-child of Jack Herer, then Cinderella99 is its Shiva Skunk-inspired step-sister. With THC rumored at nearly 28%, we unwrapped out sample from Altitude Organic Medicine with wild anticipation, and were greeted with tear-jerking super haze aroma and creamy Pine Sol blast. The entire bud was amber–pure amber, covered–and cured delicately with perfect moisture content and crumble. Ground and smoked, sharp lemon notes struck the tongue, accompanied by grapefruit, but no foul aftertaste.

Within seconds, we knew that AOMs C99 was a candidate for our Cream O The Crop award. The super-cerebral buzz zapped the forehead like two jumper cables attached to the ears. Razor-sharp and flabbergasting, the metamorphosis was magical, as if whisking our minds away to the nearest fairy-tale kingdom. Heaviest sensations settled in the face and back of throat, as all 3 critics fell into a satisfying flux, a philosophical stupor.

Other traits were noted: boldness in new situations and courage in negative ones; connectedness with the surrounding environment and people, as well as an inner peace. Speech-givers would be empowered by the C99 but speech-writers would find their inspirations difficult to transfer to paper through slowed muscle response.

Even more stunning than 2-hour psychedelic thrill-ride was the descent back to normalcy, almost completely devoid of hangover, drowsiness, sleepiness, or disorientation. It was barely noticeable. Cannoisseurs who love Super Silver Haze will find C99 potently impressive. Perfect for motivation, awful for accuracy, and 100% on psychedelic pleasure, AOMs crop is well worth the drive, by pumpkin-carriage or otherwise.

Profile: Sativa-Dominant Hybrid

Testing: No Official Testing
item.excerpt:encoded: Razor-sharp and flabbergasting, the metamorphosis was magical, as if whisking our minds away to the nearest fairy-tale kingdom. Heaviest sensations settled in the face and back of throat, as all 3 critics fell into a satisfying flux, a philosophical stupor. Continue reading →

item.title: Island Sweet Skunk (ISS) from The Green Solution
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Island Sweet Skunk (ISS)

Dispensary: The Green Solution

A great legend told ’round the fire in Canada warns of the Dungarvon Whooper, the forlorn ghost of a New Brunswick lumberjack shot in cold blood. A slightly less-told legend is that of the California Skunk #1 that disappeared in the misty mountains embracing the Salish Sea in the 1970′s, and emerged as Island Sweet Skunk. What happened to it? Which odd tropical-smelling bagseed or grower’s experiments created the now-definitive strain somewhere along the shores of George Vancouver’s island?

Either way – the strain makes a popular grow here in the higher altitudes, where a full week can be subtracted from flowering. The Green Solution sent us a sample covered in golden red hairs like pipe cleaners, dressed in a spicy pia colada aroma that flowed from the container and filled the room. The first hit brought tears to the eyes, and tickled the back of the throat. The high was strong and true to its Skunk heritage, as if a blanket had been thrown over the head from behind.

With lips buzzing, this illuminating strain made it possible to sit and watch a sunset or draw inspirations from every-day situations. Initiatives were easier to focus on, however, the motivation to do plan them dropped considerably. That said, ISS made for a great early-morning jump start, as long as a To-Do list had already been written. The well-rounded psychedelia was not impairing; veteran critics felt the effects waning after only an hour, at least considerably in terms of body sensation.

An hour and fifteen minutes into the equation, we were cognizant enough to concentrate on something as difficult as a foreign language, much less completing a puzzle. Physical accuracy was certainly difficult (i.e., archery, building a computer, etc.) until after 2 hours. Munchies weren’t heavy but shouldn’t be ruled out.

Profile: Sativa-Dominant

Testing: 13.64% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Great White Shark from Alternative Medicine on Capitol Hill (AMCH)
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Great White Shark

Dispensary: Alternative Medicine on Capitol Hill (AMCH)

What do you get when cross Skunk #1 with White Widow? If you said Peacemaker, Shark Shock, or White Shark, youd be correct. Theyre all alternative monikers for Great White Shark–which, to be perfectly anal about it, actually comes from Black Widow, the doppelganger of the original White. GWS peaked more than a decade ago in popularity, but still holds a solid place on the medicine shelf with its simple genetics and the strong signature effects of its infamous parents.

Our specimen came from AMCH, rustic and somewhat devoid of hairs, carrying the aromatic spice of nutmeg and sage. The acrid stenches from its Black Widow roots only amplified as we broke the thick bracts apart, although mixture with Skunks sweet and creamy tendencies produced a unique and colorful potpourri. It wasnt until the smoke struck the tongue that we tasted cinnamon.

The first hit broke the surface of normalcy quite abruptly; numbness riveted through the body but especially in the limbs. Thought-processes and speech were not affected, but a heavy sense of self-awareness set it. The eyes watered and all reviewers enjoyed a riveting, focused high with no sinking feeling; empowered, we were all able to work well. Two critics with lower tolerance experienced slight vertigo for the first 30-60 minutes, but nothing they couldnt handle. Munchies were strong, and one of us whorfed down a sandwich in under 45 seconds.

Particularly notable was the ravenous inspiration derived from GWS. Like a burst of a creativity to the spirit, we found the strain overwhelmingly supportive of imagination and task performance, even if the motivation to do them dropped significantly. Lucid and encouraging, we definitely felt that Peacemaker is a much more appropriate sobriquet than Great White Shark, unless the Cannoisseur has dark secrets lurking the id which must be brought to surface. Good for afternoons–probably post-lunch–the experience is worth at least a couple of high-powered hours on the beach, in the water, or traversing the murky depths of ones own thoughts.

Profile: Sativa

Testing: 13.03% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Vortex from Natures Way
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Vortex

Dispensary: Nature’s Way

Like any family tree that intertwines with itself–often seen among royal dynasties–the Jack Herer/C99/Princess mnage was bound, after a while, to produce a crazy uncle. That confused, stupid high of a sativa is none other than Vortex, the disoriented offspring of Apollo 13 and Space Queen. Its out-of-world mental mindwarp can often surprise infrequent or even veteran smokers, generating a genuine, dizzying spin.

Our sample from Nature’s Way was sparkling blonde, with great trim, few stems, and a couple red hairs. Subcool bred the strain to be tart; ours did possess a certain citrus sourness, but overall took on a more spicy apple or mango tea fragrance. The taste was bright and spring fresh, with currant notes falling on the back of the mouth.

Immediate with the first hit, an energy bolt struck the eyes and back of the head. Reeling backwards, awareness of pulse and heartbeat was the first thing on the mind. Bam. It hit hard. Dry-mouth accompanied the blast, as did a foggy cloud that doubled sensitivity to light. Some objects became silhouettes and shapes. That 1st wave lasted 30 minutes, but was still resonating tenaciously as the thought process started working again. Conversation was possible, and focus, growing. A deep relaxation ensued as the body buzz extended to all extremities, revealing attributes of Romulan and Northern Lights buried within the Vortex ancestry.

Interestingly enough, the vortex eventually arrived. Four out of 5 people felt it, at unpredictable, varying times. The most-common medicator felt it at an hour: he got dizzy. We got dizzy. Until that point, our measure of the effects had been somewhere around 7 on the Canna-Richter scale…but the light-headed and abrupt dizziness really pushed the envelope. Quickly, the craziness faded, and were were left with pulsing remnants for another 2 hours.

Three full puffs from the large bong and the afternoon was taken care of. Vortex makes a great working strain, for picnics, or even calling customer support (assuming you can sit down when the vortex strikes). Munchies were slow, but eventually resulted in a beverage and chocolate. Pain relief was not amazing, but the relaxation remained true for the entire duration. Panic-prone patients should probably stay away; existentialists may find that it’s just the experience they’ve been looking for.

Profile: Sativa

Testing: 15.87% Total Cannabinoids

That confused, stupid high of a sativa is none other than Vortex, the disoriented offspring of Apollo 13 and Space Queen. Continue reading →

item.title: Sensi Star from Green Solution
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Sensi Star

Dispensary: Green Solution

Indicas whose psychedelic essences compete with those of classic sativas, are a Cannasoirs objet a–both worlds are rarely satisfied like the Sensi Star mlange. Calm and deep, Sensi is the kind of friend your bring along to sip Manhattans and shoot pool. An excellent creative strain, it makes for great late-night inspiration, but is best for improvisation, not coloring within the lines.

Our bright orangutan-colored beast of a bud specimen boasted meaty calyxes and a creamy fragrance. It crackled as we smoked, but wasnt too harsh. Critics reported tastes ranging from apple pie to Golden Grams. A spacey high struck hard within seconds.

But there were no prophetic visions. The initial strength kept growing, rising from the middle of the chest and coursing through the body, like a sinking morphine rush. Critics were locked to their chairs, some frozen motionless in empty stares. TV was enjoyable, although these cerebral two-hit energies faded slightly after a half-hour sitcom.

Pain relief was spectacular, so much that problem solving, planning and work should be avoided (the brain will be numb as well). A sublime chill, Sensi was appropriate for video games but not computers. Patients should not medicate with previous worries on the mind; they will be driven mad with increased uneasiness.

The fog lasted about an hour, when the ability to multi-task recovered from its nosedive. Drowsiness was noted slight, but the strain still soothed the nerves for another hour. This staple strain could be good for knitting gardening, home projects, and more, but dont expect the motivation to get things accurate, perfect or symmetric. Dependable, Sensi Star was a great repertoire addition, but will burn out if smoked all day. Only one CannaCritic really caved to munchies, and he made tea for everyone.

Profile: Indica

Testing: 20.21% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Purple Dragon from Alternative Medicine on Capitol Hill (AMCH)
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Purple Dragon

Dispensary: AMCH

Dark, tart, frosty and pungent, a good Purple Dragon is worth tasting just for the novelty of palate. The delicacy begins with sight; unlike the amethyst purple of a Purple Diesel or Grape Ape, the Dragon sports monolithic hues of hibiscus or plum. Aromatic Grape Soda fills the air when ground, and boysenberry tickles the tongue when smoked. Its quintessentially delicious purp spirit will emanate strongly throughout the house with hints of Nag Champa.

Our first hits were subtle as we waited for the cannabinoids to traverse the body. Ruminating in the aftertaste was a Nobel Criollo cocoa bean, or even spicy merlot. The effects began viscerally, with pain relief starting deep within the bones and systems and progressing outward. Starting in the abdomen, the pangs of tension and joint aches disappeared. Thought-process was not affected at first; critics felt numbness most in the shoulder blades, triceps, quads, and feet.

The cerebral Dragon experience didnt kick in until 15 minutes after the initial puffs. Responsibility was difficult but moral decisions could be made. Munchies resulted in pizza rolls and other medium servings of savory foods. Everything seemed to be well-timed. The high-powered psychedelia was a pleasure and lasted just long enough to prepare food, eat and enjoy. Then a few more minutes of meditation before dazing off into a stupor.

Sitting adds weight to the Purple Dragon experience; after a while we all felt gravity pulling us considerably more than usual. This was remedied by standing, but ultimately, none of us could ignore the longing for uninterrupted slumber. Smoking this strain after a meal will almost guarantee a nap…and a P. Drag wake n bake will most definitely result in being late to work.

Profile: Sativa (By a hair – 55/45. Possibly a Purple Erkel backcross)

Testing: 20.36% Total Cannabinoids
