item.title: Phnom Penh from Colorado Alternative Health Care
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Phnom Penh

Dispensary: Colorado Alternative Health Care

While its not uncommon to find an indica flush-full of THC, its even more stunning to find a sativa whose CBD count outnumbers the THC. In Phnom Penh you have that strange mix of original Cambodian jungle-sativa, paired with the luscious and savory headrush of both Thai and Haze bred together!

Our crystal-covered morsel was gritty and coarse, marginally stemmy, but with full sugary grind. The initial smells of Vics Vapor Rub revealed in a grind, but overall, Penh was woody and floral in taste. Our first hit immediately sent us swinging through the jungle like a vicodin rush. A spicy release on the tongue, this Indochinese wonder came with an undertow. The feet became lead weights, but all other panic settled down in a calm. Breathing and heartbeat slowed. The aggression and frustrations slipped away. It was extremely peaceful.

Strategically, we waited five minutes between puffs, experiencing waves of sinking and further buzz. Relaxed, some slumped in their chairs and lost their thought process. But with surprisingly good lucidity, recognition and reflexes were still strong, if just slightly slowed.

A 2nd hit carried twice as much weight as first with considerable girth. A creative strain with some slight mind-body separation, the overall psychedelia grew magnificently, slowing nerves and cross-splicing others. The fingers typed out of order. About 2-3 minutes after second hit, a very definitive wave of warmth and heaviness passed, sort of like hard-core painkiller that finally hits the bloodstream. More than anything, it was an extreme bake, if weve ever experienced one. Nothing too visual or too psychedelic, but heady enough for novel pleasure and a strong chill-out as bonus. One could sit and watch a movie for several hours, but not without playing music, sketching, knitting, or otherwise, simultaneously.

With the CBD, we expected the Penh to put us down. But it kept going, in a zombie daze and couch lock. Given enough coffee, the strain would make a pain-ridden patients daydream come true. But it wont make a good knock-out juice at night. Chronic sufferers who find themselves on a dance floor around midnight for any reason, my survive by bringing this bowl-to-go.

Phnom Penh eventually ended it the ultimate non-sensical drowsiness as a warped numbness accelerated through the body. Critics rocked back and forth with the music and felt good vibes, noted increase in gentility, and sparking of revolutionary ideas, but absolutely no motivation or energy to see them through, much less write them down. The nadir was accompanied by a few munchies, but not without the better judgement against them.

Somewhat energized and then tired, the Phnom Penh kept consciousness careening between extremes. The mind functioned adequately even until the end, just crippled and easily stalled; critics noted several instances of stopping mid-thought to try and remember what they were saying. Keep a pen nearby to jot down your epiphanies, because once forgotten, theyre gone.

Profile: Sativa

Testing: 24.04% Total Cannabinoids (12.95% CBD!)

item.title: Recon from Natures Way
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Recon

Dispensary: Nature’s Way

Recon is one of the quixotic mystics from Himalayan highlands, the kind of resinous, sweet-and-sour buds that make relaxing Nepalese temple balls. Narcotic, this pleasurable and philosophical indica is full of THC, which is what you’d expect from a mostly Afghani pedigree with traits of an equatorial sativa-haze.

Our sample crumbled like powder puffs of a baker’s sugar. The taste was cheesy and rustic, a little peppery and with the pine potpourri one might encounter in a spa. The taste was cherry, with an antique-store sort of lilt in the smoke.

One word describes the Recon experience well: aloof. This doesn’t necessarily mean that thought-processing came to a stand-still–quite the opposite. It was a couch-locking, mind-racing confusion. The eyes felt like tight eggs, about to crack, and the extremities turned to jelly under new-found weight. We were aloof, though, and didn’t really try to focus, as the experience pushed us into a long stare at nothing, totally unaware of time’s passing. Then again, with something to stare at, one could possibly concentrate at least, after the first 30 minutes. Homework wouldn’t be easy, but it’d at least be tolerable.

Recon’s pain alleviation lasted at least two hours, while the reflexive cerebral alchemy was short and in bursts for an hour and then faded. It would make a great strain for rendezvous at the lake cabin, to watch a sunset over the water. The critics were, overall, impressed. We were enlightened and composed, even in the end (with minor burnout), but would never recommend Recon for conversational elaboration or eloquence.

A small snack should do the trick if eaten early. Expect to be in bed within the hour if medicated after 10PM.

Profile: 80% Indica

Testing: 17.43% Total Cannabinoids

See Full Results from Herbal Synergy

Narcotic, this pleasurable and philosophical indica is full of THC, which is what you'd expect from a mostly-Afghani pedigree with traits of an equatorial sativa-haze. Continue reading →

item.title: Bubble Berry from The Green Solution
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Bubble Berry

Dispensary: The Green Solution

Given its parents–Bubble Gum and Blueberry, we really hoped BubbleBerry would taste like blueberry Big League Chew. Our sample certainly had the aroma; a little bubble gum, and mostly candy. The grind seemed to mask the fruity smell well, creating a more roast marshmallow. A musky botanical taste manifested with the smoke, even pomegranate at times. The exhale was pleasant too, staying close to berry–but the artificial grocery-store version, rather than real ones.

The 1st puff was impressive. Subversive. Head-jolting and attention-grabbing, it was the sort of hit that makes you stop and wait for the brain-stem to recover from shock. There was a pleasant body buzz within seconds, but the majority of effects were cerebral. Surprisingly, the abilities to think and operate, even late at night, were enhanced. There was little loss of functionality; rather, everything became simply enjoyable.

One hit would have sufficed for half of the critics, but wed all agreed to see what two did. Each plunged us farther from true sobriety, but we did not feel intoxicated or impaired. Instead, it was an extremely workable high with little second guessing or emotional backlash. Then again, it was a difficult to sit still; movies, performances, lectures and meetings should be avoided. Veteran smokers took three hits and were good for hour, maybe more; no one really experienced psychedelia; rather, the speculative thinker emerged.

Forgetfulness became an issue for critics; the Blueberry traits were ever-present. Tensions absent from along the spine disappeared and we four sat in a very appealing languor that actually produced valid conversation, albeit slow and gallant. Never disappointing, the critics all wanted more, especially given the lack of burnout–the whole episode was light and on its feet, composed but spacy. One critic kept smoking the strain throughout the day and reported that there didnt seem to be a ceiling, that he could literally get higher and higher. Thats rare.

In general, Bubble Berry made best for when you need to be completely medicated, but want people to think otherwise. Munchies, quite appropriately, demanded sweets, and generally, a tall glass of water.

Profile: Sativa

Testing: 19.22% Total Cannabinoids

Never disappointing, the critics all wanted more, especially given the lack of burnout--the whole episode was light and on its feet, composed but spacy. Continue reading →

item.title: Django from Alternative Medicine on Capitol Hill (AMCH)
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Django

Dispensary: AMCH

Much like a donut, our copper-haired sample was caked with an amber layer of sugar. Of Django’s two parents, the Jack Flash was the more apparent in her taste than Blueberry. It broke apart to aromas of “lemon fresh garden” according to one critic, with cherry revealed in the clean, white smoke.

The senses were immediately heightened. Lights were brighter; toothpaste actually tasted good. The mind raced faster than limbs could keep up with. The body, however, was creeping. While we were paying attention to the neurons firing across the cerebellum, the shoulder and forearms suddenly numbed, followed by the presence of a full body buzz. Pain began to disappear, but so did basic movement skills. A few critics reported a sort of Hunter S. Thompson lack of body control, wherein walking, working–anything–had to be concentrated on. Stretching and exercise did fix the sensation to an extent.

For the most part, Django was cerebral and inviting, but not without doses of paranoia in dark or odd situations. It wouldn’t make a great camping strain, as every bump in the night would have smokers weeping on the picnic table and nervously shining a flashlight into the trees. Fear aside, creativity was a breeze but the inability to express ideas hampered any progress. The sense of needing to do something never subsided. One should not have a project, event or errand hanging over their head, going into a bowl.

Probably good for recreational athletics, the combination of focus and body buzz awoke the senses but kept the muscles loose. The descent was fairly smooth and without hangover; however, the relaxing vibes lingered for a good hour after the psychedelia died. Sensitive and understanding, we felt more connected with those around us, and appreciated life’s inherently good qualities. If only for the afternoon.

Profile: “Sativa” (Behaves like a 60/40 Indica, we think)

Testing: 22.68% Total Cannabinoids

It wouldn't make a great camping strain, as every bump in the night would have smokers weeping on the picnic table and nervously shining a flashlight into the trees. Continue reading →

item.title: Permafrost from Natures Way
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Permafrost

Dispensary: Nature’s Way

This time of year, thoughts of the tundra are not comforting, as the Rockies turn to a frozen wonderland in the dead of winter, life-less and bone-chilling. That said, we embrace Permafrost as a mild autumn strain. The hybrid, rumored to be White Widow and Trainwreck, is a frosty, dark-haired brute with tart orange hairs, with a mild energetic high, still worthy of the season.

Our sample from Natures Way carried a fine pine aroma, as some described mango curry. With the smoke came a hickory flavor, spicy and red hot, but not without the slightest hint of chemicals. Definitely a perfect and impressive flush.

First waves hit heavily in the cheeks. But they settled mildly everywhere else. Motivation was immediately killed by at least 25%, but we were still awake and following a slow, hour-long cerebral creeping. Processing and decision-making lagged. Thirty minutes in, we enjoyed varying degrees of a notable head-high upgrade. It was sudden, and a pleasant surprise.

We lost a majority of feeling after 1.5 hours. Numbness continued ringing in frontal lobe for up to 2.5 hours, but not uncontrollably like a sinurs headache. Potency never climbed higher than medium, but made for a good working strain, especially for physical labor. Maybe even the ideal company for kite-flying or wine-tasting.

Munchies were severe. Pizza was ordered. Great for staring off into the changing leaves, picnicking at sunset, or jamming, critics found that films/TV made for a spacey, relaxing experience, but not psychedelic (find something more cerebral before you go watch the sequel to Avatar).

Profile: Sativa-Dominant Hybrid (Grower reports Indica dominance – Could be a Northern Lights cross)

Testing: 14.04% Total Cannabinoids

See Full Results from Herbal Synergy
item.excerpt:encoded: This time of year, thoughts of the tundra are not comforting, as the Rockies turn to a frozen wonderland in the dead of winter, life-less and bone-chilling. That said, the CannaCritics embrace Permafrost as a mild autumn strain. Continue reading →

item.title: Bubba Kush from The Green Solution
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Bubba Kush

Dispensary: The Green Solution

Indica lovers appreciate Bubba Kush for its pairing of two other staples, Chem Dog (the West Coast Version) and OG Kush. Our sample came from the Green Solution, bright green and tie-dyed purple. Its blanket of hairs was the color of crimini mushrooms, and frosted in amber crystals. Classic Kush and Chemdawg aromas permeated the bag deliciously and exploded during the grind. We were surprised to find a lone seed, but not put out; the bud made up for it, and the seed disappeared quickly. Smoked, the BK revealed a dark and resinous taste and crisp grape innuendo with bitter finish.

Bubba Kushs first hits were strongly body, but not intense. Although psychedelic and visual aspects made veritable appearances, the creeping head largely enhanced focus, but wounded accuracy fatally. Some disorganization lagged, as heaviness and numbness hung upon the spine like Valerian. Critics agreed that the strain was of medium potency and best for a late-afternoon chill-out high. Fogginess was light, not like the super-impressive blast from its Lemon Thai roots like some Bubba Kush variations.

A few of us considered the BK appropriate for picnics with family, but two critics reported it as a sort of downer; neither was super-happy. But that changed for everyone as we caved for completely ludicrous munchies and inhaled ice cream and beer (expect to be a sucker for sweets in general). The body was in a lull for about an hour but came out without exhaustion. All-day smoking would burn anyone out. Also be prepared for light sensitivity and watery eyes – no hiding this one from loved ones or co-workers.

Profile: Indica

Testing: 17.64% Total Cannabinoids

See Full Results from Herbal Synergy
item.excerpt:encoded: Strain: Bubba Kush Dispensary: The Green Solution Indica lovers appreciate Bubba Kush for its pairing of two other staples, Chem Dog (the West Coast Version) and OG Kush. Our sample came from the Green Solution, bright green and tie-dyed purple. … Continue reading →

item.title: Golden Goat from The Healing House
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Golden Goat

Dispensary: The Healing House

This signature bud gets our Cream of the Crop stamp, and not just because it recently won Patients Choice at the September industry Hash Bash. The strain comes with a sort of po-dunk history of displaced coastal and tropical phenotypes mistakenly bumping into each other in Nowhere, Kansas. While Golden Goat doesnt exactly smell like the dumpsters from which its moniker is taken, its pungently sweet tropical essences are only the prelude to its legendary cerebral effects.

The Healing House treated us to a meaty bud with splotches of orchid purple, covered in cherry-blond crystals and a mane of pumpkin-orange hairs. The scent was strong and sweet; two critics claimed it as a Sauvignon Blanc, notably the exotic Nobilo from New Guinea, known for its palate of gooseberries and passion fruit (the buds grind and taste was reminiscent of a fresh-squeezed Brazilian Maracuja). Need we say more? This Goat was fruity. Its frosted bud smoked with an oak finish.

1st waves were a combination relaxation of nerves and settled in like an invisible hat, creeping into the face, then, by five minutes through torso and arms. Though psychedelic indeed, focus was still intact and critics felt they could function. One noted increased motivation and hope almost immediately. We were not easily distracted as we fell into productive, mechanical rhythms, accomplishing tasks instead of relaxing. Perception and precision were enhanced. Innovation and creativity, were, surprisingly, hampered. Stupid mistakes were made and in general, a sweeping fogginess hugged the cranium.

The strain also soothed and we all noticed tense nerves subside. One critic reported their mood had turned 180 degrees from sour to self-actualized. The muscles were bound and ready for two hours, performing repetitive tasks with what felt like refined accuracy (although personal results will vary). Flight simulators or home projects may seem easier and fun, as well as roller-skating the local disco-rink. Free-form philosophers and improvising musicians will want to read or at least answer a question rather than create from scratch. In fact, fleeing the mental beaten path on any analogical level will only lead to major freakout, especially for those with a paranoid aversion to strong sativas.

In all, Golden Goat made us more efficient people, and was worth the excitement. The whole experience could last 3 to 3.5 hours for some patients, and was a great fundamental addition to our collection. A Cream of the Crop, indeed…

Profile: Sativa (I.S.S. x (Hawaiian Sativa x Romulan)

Testing: 17.20% Total Cannabinoids

See Full Results from Herbal Synergy
item.excerpt:encoded: The scent was strong and sweet; two critics claimed it as a Sauvignon Blanc, notably the exotic Nobilo from New Guinea, known for its palate of gooseberries and passion fruit (the buds grind and taste was reminiscent of a fresh-squeezed Brazilian Maracuja) Continue reading →

item.title: Karma Chews from North Shore Edibles
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Product: Karma Chews

Dispensary/MIPs: North Shore Edibles (Sold At Karmaceuticals)

Karma Chews are the latest in the line of chewable candy competitors that include veterans like Cheeba Chews and the orange-toffee Benjamin Rolls. The candys producer, North Shore, claims that each Karma Chew sports 200mg THC. So how does the candy compare to predecessors?

The good things is that Karma Chews are gourmet caramels, like butter-packed Knudsens that peel away from their wax paper with greasy ease. The confection was luxurious and nutty, with a toasted aroma and silk-smooth texture. As for taste – it was a mixture of that bright and soft caramel taste, with juxtaposition of a more bitter and acrid cannabis. The medicinal flavor was almost overpowering, if not for just enough sugary edge to balance; in all it was delicious but hard to handle (some of us critics who like to eat plain kief did not have a problem).

We each ate a whole one, over the course of fifteen minutes, and talked edibles. Compared to a Cheeba, the Karmas initial hit was softer (but similarly sudden and definitive). Within 30 minutes, though, its power had grown faster and more aggressively than a traditional hybrid quad-dose. The torso sunk as if inhabited by an alien and more than two of us felt a need for coffee. Vision was also becoming erratic but enjoyable, and critics reported varying sensitivities to light (the most common being the color blue, saturating the environment).

At the one-hour mark, the female in the group reported temporary shortness of breath. Others marked difficulty with mental tasks like decision-making and syntax. Amiability was up across the board. Critics by hour two were watching the sunset and nostalgically reminiscing. There was no hangover-heaviness or cloudiness. The clarity was refreshing. Morning chewers would likely be productive with Karmas (coffee/tea may be in order) but night chewers will become ramblers of tall tales. Those burning the midnight oil will find their motivation, shot.

At almost three hours came a major shift in fogginess, especially for those on empty stomachs. It began rising stupidly as we enjoyed hors d’oeuvres around the fire, and grew until very obvious that there were climbing new levels of both cerebral nuttiness and pain relief.

When it comes to edibles, its not unusual for one of our critics to experience less than the rest; everyone is different, and sometimes metabolism, genes, diet, and other unknown factors can affect results. This was true for one of our veteran smokers. It was Harris. An 1/8oz/day smoker, he said that the candy came on strong as mentioned above, then died almost immediately. He waited the full eight hours for any more effects, then promptly started smoking hash through an apple.

Another with high tolerance said the high was mild, and lasted about 5 hours. The majority of critics felt it no longer than six hours, but with much stronger potency.

Profile: 60/40 Indica (from Package)

Testing: 13.83% Total Cannabinoids

See Full Results from Herbal Synergy

item.title: Sour Kush from Alternative Medicine on Capitol Hill (AMCH)
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Sour Kush

Dispensary: AMCH

Like the beautifully mystic bastard child of Lady and the Tramp, Sour Kush mixes Sour Diesels renegade melange of worldy genetics with the well-manicured MK-Ultra, a breeders choice. Our first such encounter with the strain came from AMCH, vibrantly colored as a blue spruce with kief cover like fresh snow. Its squirrely buds were thick and compact, with kush-like bracts and hints of purple. It was sweet and spicy when ground, like nutmeg with a subtle cherry. The sample was limited and critics only experienced two full hits, at most. But cazart, was it more than enough.

Blonde as it was, we werent prepared for the breathtaking first hit – even a conservative corner of the bud rocked hard for 15 straight seconds, with a generous release on exhale. Then, the massive fogginess dissipated, leaving major back-end creeper to round up. The taste revealed a sort of earthiness, but all aromas, especially sour, were devoid from the actual palate (they hung in the smoke). A strong dark coffee bean roast finish followed.

Intense brain lock set in, with all of the pulsing body waves and tingling, pressure-lifting bliss of ChemDawg, but sans focus. Pains like sore wrists and neck cricks disappeared, but motivation was shot. The high was resinous, with different waves reminiscent of Sour Kushs Northern Lights and Skunk ancestry. Uplifting but soothing, the bud worked especially for post-work exhaustion and aches.

One critic was ancy, moreso than the rest, but we all agreed, we didnt feel like doing anything. Spastic, unpredictable muscle movement was not uncommon. Creative epiphanies emerged from exhilarating introspection. One starry-eyed reviewer wrote that the cannabis strain made …a fine visage to accompany an old man and his cat, as he takes in the view from the shores at the center of the universe. Eerily, that critic was ill-acquainted with Douglas Adams.

The mind sped and slowed, ebbed and flowed, but the heart was not pounding. This would make a great one-hitter bowl for those in a hurry. One or two puffs will definitely suffice for any smoker, even those with certified high-tolerance. But given its insane power, patients should medicate with S.K. in a controlled environment with gentle stimuli. Awkward or tense situations could put traditional indica lovers face-to-face with danger and paranoid fears, while sativa lovers can expect to endure a numb body that doesnt want to move. Plan for a minimum 2.5-hour experience, with munchies, psychedelia, and loud music.

Profile: Critics assume 65% Indica; Grower suggests Sativa Dominance

Testing: 29.69% Total Cannabinoids

Full Results from Herbal Synergy

One starry-eyed reviewer wrote that the cannabis strain made ...a fine visage to accompany an old man and his cat, as he takes in the view from the shores at the center of the universe. Eerily, that critic was ill-acquainted with Douglas Adams." Continue reading →

item.title: Hawaiian Haze from The Green Solution
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Hawaiian Haze

Dispensary: The Green Solution

Given its lengthy flowering cycle, you dont see much Hawaiian Haze on the desert plain. Green Solutions rare sample was a very convincing find. Crystal-blonde as the sands of Waikiki, its aroma was that of a Cambodian Mekong Haze, somewhere between tropical fruit snack and mint julep.

The first effects hit between the eyes like covert arsenal, a swift strike that took us by surprise. The head swirled in confusion as the body adjusted; visuals were sudden and colorful, but not far-out. By the second hit, we were overcome by a tidal wave of Aloha spirit that lasted for a good hour. Our lowest-tolerance reviewer had to sit down.

Although the strain made us forgetful, it was uplifting overall and even giggly at times, especially for the second hour. Gracefully, we relaxed as the narcotic body of H.H.s mystery indica grandparent emerged, giving gravity to the arms and legs.

Driving and energetic, this beautiful bud might be appropriate for any work conference or casual afternoon jaunt walking the dog. A great mood-setter for sentimental situations, a lone puff would be fitting for a romantic date or even the Friday night ball game. The eyes werent tight, red, or watery, and it was possible to fake sobriety and seriousness, but only in low doses.

There were bouts of dry mouth. Munchies were also widespread. As critic Orson put it, Once I started eating, I could not, would not, stop. Others reported that they were happily able to concentrate on endeavors, but had lost the ability to multi-task. Finally, the strains most rave review celebrated that Hawaiian Haze brought upon a slightly impaired judgement, but not a compromise of ones morals.

Profile: Mostly Sativa

Testing: 18.12% Total Cannabinoids

See Full Results from Herbal Synergy
item.excerpt:encoded: "Blonde as the sands of Waikiki, its aroma was that of a Cambodian Mekong Haze, somewhere between tropical fruit snack and mint julep." Continue reading →

item.title: Krypto Diesel from The Green House
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Krypto Diesel

Dispensary: The Green House

Kryptonite was a popular MTV-era Kush with Southeast Asian flavors, and probably named for Supermans disabling antithesis. Its union with an East Coast Diesel–probably from the Big Apple–enmeshed a random and colorful lineage that resembles a Jackson Pollack. The aroma and grind of Green Houses selection carried strong sugary tones of apricot and plum, lacking much of the typical citrus Diesel smell.

Starting with a strong blow to the head, the initial blast mellowed quickly. Cross-eyed critics returned to focused, functional people within the first half-hour and a body hum set in. The sensation was thematically scored by the thaumaturge Rachmaninoff, whose piano concerto mirrored our subtle but growing waves of sublimation and numbness. The nerves reposed, every one. One allergy-prone critic noted a hollowness between the eyes as even the sinuses contracted and expanded. There was no pressure; just a heady sort of release through the nasal cavities.

Well-balanced, the K.D. was a mood elevator. Maybe, even, a peace-with-the-universe sort of strain, where rainbows seem brighter and the animals approach you as genteel equals. Dont expect to crave munchies, but rather, a stiff cocktail. Duration can last 1.5-3 hours, so make that–two cocktails. Perfect for disarming any work-related tension, Krypto-D is a great early-evening strain: genuine relaxation, mixed with grinning refreshment.

Profile: Indica Dominant (Roughly 75%)

Testing: 13.85% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Fruit Jellies from Edi-Pure
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Product: Fruit Jellies

Edibles Company: Edi-Pure

Gummies have historically been rare when searching for edibles with novelty, although its difficult to reason why: as long as infusion occurs after the fact, there doesnt seem to be any reason not to follow one of the easiest-known confection recipes (not to mention the a crowd favorite). Among patients, theres hardly any more uncharted territory than candy – and often the companies leading the pack cant keep up with demand.

Edi-Pures Fruit Jellies are not like gummy bears, with the greasy, rubbery consistency (much like Madam Mary Janes fish and gigantic Grateful Dead-style bear gummies). Instead, they are sugar-covered fruit slices, a gourmet variety pack version of the popular bright-orange fruit jelly-candies that greet you at the gas station and when youre ringing up at Safeway. The company is adamant about the accuracy of dosing, with a very specific infusion process overseen by an actual medical doctor. Each slice (5 come to a pack) was individually dosed, one at a time, at 25mg THC each. And they werent lying.

The first slice was lemon. Even with a lite snack preceding the edible to initiate metabolism, the 25mg delivered a pleasant surprise. 1st effects took minutes, starting in the front of the head. Next came waves of levity, counterbalanced by a distinct heaviness extending throughout the torso. As for the gooey goodness, taste was impressively delicious with only the slightest earthiness; be warned that dry throat may follow the swallow, as pockets of hash coarsed down the esophagus.

Five minutes after the first, a grape slice was sampled to speed things up. The addition was electrifying. The candy itself was almost brown with hash and certainly spicier, perhaps by accident, but again, the taste was superb and the effects, immediate. A floating sensation continued and creativity abounded. With a snap of energy, enhanced focus accompanied the heaviness, due to a mystical, spastic force moving us. But jitters were not a problem. Couch lock was. After only fifteen minutes, critics were pinned to their chairs. One reviewer had medicated throughout the day up until 3 hours before testing, and reported that the slices hit hard. It also piqued the loyalty of a critic who doesnt typically prefer edibles.

Over the next half-hour, the THC made its way into the bloodstream, just from the 50mg. Serenity set in. There was a peaceful moment when the heart slowed and all auditory buzzes seemed to disappear. Another piece was consumed: orange. It was a truly gourmet version of the check-out lane confection, and delicious. But it was not a bright synthetic color, rather its blood orange tint and flavor were rich and smooth. Critics began to suspect that letting the chunks get caught in the teeth is a good thing, because the high seems to come on quickly with a sub-lingual dissolve.

Vision was slightly affected. As the cerebral effects grew, it was obvious that the dosage was accurate. Three slices had already achieved a ringing buzz, pain relief with solid head high. Never debilitating or impairing (not enough to turn someone into a watery-eyed moron) it did possess the best qualities from both ends of the sativa/indica spectrum.

For an hour, the waves grew–but a plateau occurred after about 75 mg despite eating the whole bag. Still, the effects were distinct and lasting, especially a haunting heaviness that can last 4 hours with a meal and up to 8 hours without. At times euphoric and foggy, expect munchies to climax around 2-3 hours during the experience, and at full force.

Though it was extremely difficult to eat such a snack one piece at a time and spread out, we were instant fans of the new candy. However, both cherry and lime flavors were somewhat harder to enjoy; the cherry was reminiscent of cough syrup, and the lime had a very medical/sterile taste, almost as if eating candy from a latex glove. It makes a good case for an orange-flavor-only bag in the future, like gas station checkout lanes – which seems to suggest that the market research has already been done. Now for medicated circus peanuts or Sour Patch Kids.

Profile: Behaves like Hybrid

Testing: 125 mg per package, 5 dosages (25mg each)

item.title: Jilly Bean from Burnzwell
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Jilly Bean

Dispensary: Burnzwell

Jilly Bean is a tasters choice bud, the kind of bud you smoke for the exotic flavor. The hybrid combines the tangy cream of Orange Skunk–technically, Orange Velvet–and Space Queen, a fruity descendant of Romulan and C99, to produce a delicious and thick morsel that grinds like a pink jelly bean. Our sample from Burnzwell was bright green with fiery neon hairs and large calyxes. The thick, well-cured nugs found a perfect balance between fluffiness and density.

Ground, the JB erupted like a gooey gumdrop, with an aroma disputed between mango and plum. The grind and burn revealed additional floral tones, and even the smoke was aromatically pleasant. Our first hit struck first in the face and neck, inducing a major swallowing reflex. The focus remained intact, as a calm settled in. But critics were still energetic enough to enjoy the growing cerebral impairment, which only tripled with a second puff.

One critic reported that after only 15 minutes, walking was awkward and that he had to second-guess every step for a while. Indeed, motor skills went downhill for awhile. Seasoned veterans may remain somewhat functional, but all other patients should avoid large doses during until night or over the weekend.

Forgetfulness and self-introspection increased, as did mood elevation–but be warned that negative moods or feelings can become enhanced as well. That said, the possibilities are great for sunny day errands, but depressing for rainy days. Jilly B also makes for a great road-tripping strain, adding warmth to landscapes and casual conversation. For 2+ hours we enjoyed the bud, with hopes to return for more. It was a perfect combination of taste and chill without the embarrassing nuttiness and zone-out.

Profile: Indica Dominant (Critics Assume 70/30 I/S)

The hybrid combines the tangy cream of Orange Skunk--technically, Orange Velvet--and Space Queen, a fruity descendant of Romulan and C99, to produce a delicious and thick morsel that grinds like a pink jelly bean." Continue reading →

item.title: Green Kure from The Herbal Medical Institute
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Product: The Green Kure (Medicated Juice)

MIPs Producer: The Herbal Medical Institute

Almost no legend precedes an edible as much as The Green Kure, HMI’s elixir for “serious health problems.” One critic tested his sample before the rest and came back to warn us. Hed taken a dose and noted a drastic change in conversation and spasticity while simultaneously sinking. Then, he took another sip. That was a mistake, he reported. His eyes reddened and he became clumsy. It was impossible to hide that I was high. At 300mg , Green Dragon Elixir is a whopper of an edible. Its a drink with remarkable after-taste that can be both tongue-twisting, or addictive, depending on your palate. Most will reel a little bit with the grapefruit/mangosteen triumphing over an otherwise insane cannabis base, the expected precursor to a spectacular high experience. If you can stomach a strong edible for the results– rather than gourmet taste–expect to be blown back to medieval times. Just dont try HMI’s mega-concentrated bottle (over 800mg THC) without proper supervision.

The first sip did have immediate effects, eaten about 1.5 hours after lunch. A rising sensation whopped the body with messy resilience, spazzing nerves in some limbs while anchoring the posterior firmly in its chair. Functionality did remain intact but there were slight associations to paranoia and difficulty concentrating. A poetic critic froze in self-introspection. Just two sips for a seasoned veteran meant a good 6-10 doses per bottle, certainly worth the retail range of $20-$25, at least. Three Simply Pure bars can go for $25-30.

And be careful. The first time is big and magical, and…dangerous.

No one–no one–should drink more than one or two sips to begin. Its effect was almost shocking. The growing warmth enhanced motor skills and hand-eye coordination (conjured epiphanies could be translated to paper rather effortlessly, and quickly). In general, a riveting haze settled in, vision skewed (colors changed) and the feeling was one of something stronger than just cannabis. It took a while to adjust to the new sensations, easily over a half-hour before some respectable sense of normalcy was reached again. For that half-hour, conversation was extremely difficult.

The Canna Critics agreed to dose in sips, rather than down the whole bottle immediately. Green Dragon does offer less-potent versions of their elixirs; even low doses seem to do the trick. One critic reportedly added the dose to a shot of orange juice and felt it through the morning. Dont expect to be completely productive after ingestion; rather have projects planned and ready to go, and dont expect to much of your accuracy.

Some melted into a solid stare and others, energized. Green Dragon apparently walks the tight line of 50/50 with respectable cerebral impairment that is matched like no other body buzz. Do have water nearby and avoid hot lights or too much sun. The critics reported several effects, many unique and many shared–but 45 minutes after taking the first swigs, we knew one thing: we were all nuts.

Time slowed considerably for the next hour. The four reviewers were split after a while: two felt tired and couldnt move, while the other two reported good awareness. The spastic energy still left them nervously rocking and fidgeting, though. Adding another sip into the mix did not create an insane high at the 2-hour mark. It may have prolonged the duration, but there was no psychoactive spike in cannabinoids.

After the major waves had worn off from the first few sips, at about 3.5 hours into things, we each finished the rest of the bottle, about 150mg remaining. The effects were different from the initial–while the first few moments or hour were more subdued, the after-effects, reaching the 2-3 hour mark, went ballistic with munchies and lethargy. Taken after a long day, expect the same reaction as a couple valerian pills – zoned out and right to bed.

The bottle does require refrigeration, unfortunately, and is not a good mainstay for medicating while traveling. However, it makes a great candidate for the post-work experience. Anticipate steady motivation to accomplish goals, with distractions twice as hard to ignore. A bottle could keep 1 person going for 1-2 days if spaced evenly and with good duration between dosing.

Profile: 50/50 Sativa/Indica (According to Manufacturer)

Testing: 300mg THC, 16mg CBD, and 7mg CBN according to label
item.excerpt:encoded: No one--no one--should drink more than one or two sips to begin. Its effect was almost shocking. The growing sensation enhanced motor skills and hand-eye coordination (conjured epiphanies could be translated to paper rather effortlessly, and quickly). In general, a riveting haze settled in, vision skewed (colors changed) and the feeling was one of something stronger than just cannabis. Continue reading →

item.title: Beyond Mars Yummy Gummy
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Product: Beyond Mars Yummy Gummy

MIPS Producer: Eleutherian Enterprises

Beyond Mars Yummy Gummy is a unique edible, presented like the after-school snacks from our 1980s childhoods. Manufacturer Eleutherian Enterprises combines the savory sweet and sour of a grapefruit jelly, and packages the pieces in such a way that they remain gooey, rich and tasty. The candy goes down with a sort of hashy after-burn in the back of the throat, but otherwise, the delicious confection is potential staple. Its an irresistible tropical take on Sunkists MTV-era fruit snacks that resembled the fruit they tasted like.

Yummy Gummies employ a full melange of tastes, including strawberry, pomegranate, and blueberry. Seventy milligrams of THC doesnt sound like much, especially when youve never bought a pack of gummies for $9-11 – but the pickup is worth the price. The first pieces brought on a heaviness and immediate buzz of self-introspection and slowed muscle response. Lights shone brighter and seemed to refract in every direction.

A note to parents: anyone, including kids, grandparents, and baby-sitters, would devour this gourmet bag of fruit snacks without thinking twice. Make sure to find a good hiding place. The results would be fairly catastrophic; it is impossible to ignore the physiological shift in cognitive ability and hand-eye coordination that could shock the unprepared. It was accompanied with a change in mood, transforming a bland day into spiritual reflection that only resulted, really, in casual depression. Not for the emo philosopher.

Hoping the candy would never end, were were please to find that the bag kept giving. A good 10-13 pieces seemed to last forever, well-prolonging the guilt from eating an entire bag (hard not to do). In the name of science, we still ate the whole thing. A stately buzz set in throughout the body by 30 minutes. Obvious and present, it did not overpower. Memory loss, however, was a significant side-effect.

Between 1-2 Hours the heaviness came on aggressively; some critics left for coffee. Munchies were mild but definite for the first hour and a half, then settled down. A dulling sensation crept over the body for a while and the relief was recorded for up to 3 or 4 hours. The psychedelic aspects of the gummies were felt stronger and with more clarity well into digestion, introducing newer waves to a befuddled brain. Processing lagged and gravity increased. The high ended most poignantly in the face, with cerebral haze sitting upon the eyes for the last hour (keep drinking those fluids).

Beyond Mars gummies could be accepted as a standard with the right kind of marketing and distribution. Patients perceive more value for the price, both from potency and unit quantity. Plus, the outcome is comparable to a Cheeba Chew, but administered in a more popular confection recipe. If the fruit snacks can expand to incorporate other flavors and shapes, Eleutherian may strike a real chord with the gas-station candy-aisle generation.

Profile: Unknown

Testing: 70mg THC, according to label
item.excerpt:encoded: "The candy goes down with a sort of hashy after-burn in the back of the throat, but otherwise, the delicious confection is potential staple. Its an irresistible tropical take on Sunkists MTV-era fruit snacks that resembled the fruit they tasted like." Continue reading →

item.title: Tincture from Rest & Relaxation
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Product: Washington Cherry Tincture

MIPS Producer: Rest and Relaxation

Like the bright and inspiring cherry tree so admirably chopped down by our first president, so was Rest and Relaxations tincture, essentially a cherry cordial without the almond champagne. While nowhere near as rich as a cinnamon schnapps or likewise, drinking the whole bottle would prove difficult. Much too rich and sweet for the taste buds. Each of our three critics agreed upon of the bottle. The dosage was digested 1.5 hours after lunch.

The elixirs first effects were felt behind the forehead. A lifting rush ensued, much like floating, and the experience was ethereal for several minutes. Cerebral effects followed, accompanied by slight jitters and paranoid thoughts. The heart raced while the mind settled into the high, and conversation was difficult.

The tincture was great for a slow afternoon, and large doses should be reserved for weekends off. The thought process slowed significantly. A very obvious buzz was noted at even 10 minutes in, and lasted for the first hour. Forgetful and dazed, all physical action came to a crawl. Handwriting, conversation, and lucid/linear thoughts were easily interrupted.

As far a pain relief goes, one critic most celebrated pain alleviation at the back of the neck. A major shift was marked at 30 minutes, and intrinsic peace was felt around 1.5 hours. We werent so numb, or even high as we were light-bodied. Mental heaviness increased and muscle response dropped to a climactic crawl between 2-3 hours for each critic. Our high-tolerance patient reported that the alleviation lasted 3 hours, the others felt it for up to 8 hours.

Munchies resulted mainly in thirst, with some chocolate cravings. Overall, the classic Flo concentration was intact, but all physical, mental and/or emotional responses were strained, stupid, and unfocused. Near the end, reviewers felt tired, but not enough to pass out.

Profile: Flo – 60/40 Sativa/Indica

Testing: Not Available
item.excerpt:encoded: "Like the bright and inspiring cherry tree so admirably chopped down by our first president, so was Rest and Relaxations tincture, essentially a cherry cordial without the almond champagne. While nowhere near as rich as a cinnamon schnapps or likewise, drinking the whole bottle would prove difficult." Continue reading →

item.title: Bruce Banner #3 from The Cannasseur Dispensary
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Bruce Banner #3

Dispensary: Mile High Wellness Center (The Cannasseur Dispensary)

Like two sides of a comic book mutant, Bruce Banner has received both praise as a choice bud, as well as criticism for overrated novelty. It all depends on who you ask, but to assess the BB just right, you have to measure its ability to transform normal people into hulking monsters quickly and mercilessly. Our sample from Mile High Wellness Center–a dispensary that advertises its Cannasseur status–was certainly some of the best Banner weve seen. In fact, their selection was a runner-up for our Cream of the Crop award, if it hadnt been pulled early. The crystals were all still bright and milky, as if just about to start ripening.

Otherwise, the bronze-haired buds were strongly aromatic, even as they tumbled from the jar. Its smell was mostly diesel. Ground, the bowl took on a very apricot spice, like a medium-dry Schloss-Vollrad Riesling. It revealed additional layers of gingerbread, especially when smoked, adding pine in the finish. The foodie-reviewers recommended a pairing with curries and soft cheeses.

The first puff pulverized strongly in the frontal lobe, through the jaw and bridge of the nose. An elevator sensation followed. Intense but localized well, clarity increased and muscle movement carried a new buoyancy. Extremely heady, and endearing, focus came and went. Over time, remedial waves swept lightly across the limbs, like water.

The 3rd puff was breathtaking and somewhat Flo-like. A solid chill and mellow high, Banner displayed borderline burnout-potential if smoked late or after large meals. The appetite was suppressed for a while, until food was actually present. It seems that some phenotypes can exhibit deep Haze, Diesel, or Kush roots from either Strawberry Diesel or OG Kush parents. In this instance we most felt the narcotic Chemdawg and Lemon Thai effects more than anything.

Good for dogma and mood-setting in general, critics found it was best to stay standing and avoid couch-vegetation. Creative and motivational, the strain was also amiable and social. Analytical but with little drive, one critic summed up the experience as having a 2-hour urge to relax without the ability to. Many of us felt a sinking near the end, appropriate for napping or even post-dinner pass-out. Morning use may require ample coffee and a deadline, maybe a newspaper.

Profile: Sativa

Testing: 22.63% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Sour Dawg from Dank LLC
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Sour Dawg

Dispensary: Dank LLC

Like its official counterpart, Fuel, the Sour Dawg is an enticing combination of two staples, Sour D and Chemdawg. Our specimen from Dank LLC was golden as if frosted by the hand of midas, from bracts to crystals, all adorning a floret of fluorescent green. The taste was most definitely chem with hints of kush and a faint grapefruit innuendo.

Sour Dawgs first hit was rip-tearing. Its performance was immediately grounding, if not melting, followed with swallowing reflex. It was important to swallow as the reflex dictated; like a Lambs Bread out of control, to lose control and lag behind was to risk regurgitation. A massive rip from any large glass piece would solicit gagging from even the strong of heart.

Each critic was greeted with a superb head hat and artful chill. The strain was far above mild-loving cannabis patients. Our moods were not elevated, however. Stale moments passed without inspiration, temples under pressure. But after twenty minutes, the relaxing tides increased, certainly counter balancing the mornings coffee.

The biggest side effect was a complete erasure of all thoughts, relevant memories, plans, etc. Wiped clean. By the 3rd hit, spelling became difficult and an overwhelming fogginess signaled that the nexus had been reached. Only one person was down and out, with the rest of us walking the edge of a debilitating experience appropriate for home consumption only. Time became hazardous and even as good ideas emerged from a frozen conscience, no one could really convey their observations in detail.

The capacity for mental dead-ends and painful reminiscing was heightened as realizations and recollections presented themselves in good and bad extremes. That is, sour attitudes or personal conflicts worsened for two critics, so its best to go into Sour Dawg smoke with kind vibes and a blank to-do list. At one hour, still resonating, work was difficult. Social interaction was sentimental and sincere.

Spectacular for the weekend, Jimmy Johns was contacted for munchies. Even after a full lunch, the high continued its ascent. The dazzling frontal lobe cloud lasts up to 3-4 hours, making it a great sleeper with timing. Critics also thought the strain would be good for tailgating (in moderation) or rainy day art projects. Absolutely the worst strain for presentations, performances, or major responsibility.

Profile: Indica-Dominant Hybrid

Testing: 16.84% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Blue Dream from Alternative Medicine on Capitol Hill (AMCH)
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Blue Dream

Dispensary: AMCH

An American-made classic, Blue Dream is like Apple Pie or Thanksgiving. Though it has been used in newer exotic fusions like Green Dream, the original works like a 1968 Pontiac: its built twice as strong and works just as well as long as you get it in good condition. Our sample from AMCH was subdued; unlike the unmistakable aroma from its Blueberry or Super Silver Haze parents, ours possessed very few qualities flavor-wise. There was sweetness, but even that was more earthy and mineral, almost like curating fresh cement. But its dense nugs were nearly white with barely-amber crystals, and ground, she was like Goldilocks in the bowl.

The high was hypnotically cerebral, with a rushing levity to forehead, cheeks and forearms. The eyes, too, took immediately to the whirlwind, but focus remained intact. Critics gave an informal thumbs up after 2 puffs–that was all we really needed. Social interaction improved, although we were genuinely blown away and had occasional problems putting thoughts into words.

One suggested that he was starting to double-think his decisions; another mentioned that hed taken a shower after medicating and suffered major short-term memory loss. He admitted to applying shampoo at least 2 or 3 times–he couldnt remember. Other reviewers reported adequate functionality while handling duties, but occasionally found themselves staring off into space.

Over time, the body extended to the extremities as the cerebral effects plateaued. One critic reported marked sensations in the back of the throat, whatever that meant, while another raved about having the courage to make some tough phone calls. Blue Dream is perfect for the early-morning sales meeting, he wrote. But in moderation. In moderation.

No major munchies were recorded, but one reviewer wrote that [it] unleashed the drunk inside me. Best for late morning or early afternoon, we recommend Blue Dream for its dependable and dreamy savoir faire, assuming the smell and crystal cover have fully developed during cure. Painkilling properties climaxed around hour two, with the experience lasting 3-4 hours in general.

Profile: Grower Suggest Indica (Editors Give it 70/30 S/I)

Testing: 19.70% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Super Lemon Haze from The Green Solution
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Super Lemon Haze

Dispensary: The Green Solution

An exclusive Hollywood family can be like the glamorous marriage of acclaimed cannabis, especially when it carries the clout of actual cup-winners. Fans worldwide wait not only for the chance to sample the strain when it pops up locally–but theyre even more excited to see the offsprings accomplishments and beauty, traits from such refined and celebrated parents.

Super Lemon Haze is a classic cup strain, a child of two winners: Super Silver Haze, an analogous Lloyd Bridges to Lemon Skunks Dorothy. Their offspring has been a successful bloomer, renowned and showered with honors for its narcotic durability and indisputable potency. We studied a tight little specimen from The Green Solution, with red hairs like Christmas and a bright lemon spice grind.

Known for its energizing powers, our critics decided to review the strain at different times of the day. Even at 11:30 PM, the bud was galvanizing. The first wave was very loose with a creeping laid-back relaxation, good for conversation. A nice fog settled in, inquisitive and philosophical, but nothing groovy. The later it was smoked, the greater the chance for extended zone-out. Distractions doubled with noise.

Panic-prone patients beware: something about the strain’s nose-tingling, cross-eyed high can bring doubts and fears into focus. When a high-strung person is stressed, SLH has the potential to only exacerbate the tension. Mindful dosing is the real answer. Although a cosmic Neverland was never reached, the creeping cerebral high and vibrations throughout the core were only workable in smaller doses spread throughout the day.

Munchies resulted in fig newtons and ice cream. An hour after medicating, a few reviewers still noted hiccups in syntax and prolonged emotional numbness. Personal planning and awareness remained strong, and, dosed well, the strain was appropriate for everyday routines. SLH is not weekend party strain for letting the hair down. Critics voted it more resembled a 5pm soccer practice strain, when you can watch your kid from the side lines with a beer and book in hand.

Profile: Sativa

Testing: 18.89% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Trixie from Cannasseur
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Trixie

Dispensary: The Cannasseur Dispensary

Other than sounding like Gollums assessment of Mordors dreaded Orcs, Trixie carries connotations of both the Bible Belt (Trinity) and coastal hedonism (OG Kush) in all its Americana splendor. Our sample from Cannasseur was a tender bud, with violets ranging from nonchalant pink to deep purple. Its wintery cover of sugar was prelude to the chem taste and smell.

The first wave hit like a classic purple diesel, with the kind of mental block that prevents ideas from fully manifesting, accompanied by a dose of relaxed nerves. Hardly overpowering, the high grew like a blanket thrown overhead and actually hit stronger 10 minutes after the puff than during. Concentration and organization became impossible, and motivation suffered miserably. Critics agreed: if not a Cream of The Crop, Trixie was a definitive, hard-to-beat runner-up.

A second hit rattled the brain more severely, giving way to simple distraction, lackadaisical meandering, and lost stares. Television played a major role; dont expect to get anything done with any stimuli nearby and blaring. Sitting in a comfortable chair was reason enough to rationalize putting projects aside regardless of deadline, and to bask in the all-around laziness.

A stately buzz snuck throughout the body as the frenzied mental vibrations seemed to sponge us into a long afternoons daze. These sensations slowed after an hour, but it was clear the strain was not for heavy consumption unless at home. In fact, Trixie is absolutely the wrong choice for work-day relief. Without moderation, cognitive awareness suffered to the point of embarrassing behavior. Certainly not the kind of strain to sample before going on a first date, or showing up for a traditional Jewish bris.

As one critic put it, Trixie is a good do-nothing selection, brilliant for chess games. Then again, slackers will slack twice as hard, and projects will be finished out of order. Improvisational rhythms seemed to flow, but the high did plateau at two hits, and duration was a definitive three hours. Make sure a clock is nearby, or risk losing your day. Perfect for the absent-minded professor, gamers and thinkers, remarked an impressed reviewer. Ergo, bad for talking and going somewhere.

Profile: Hybrid

Testing: 18.86% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Chem Dawg 4 from Dank LLC
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Chem Dawg 4

Dispensary: Dank LLC

You can tell good Chemdawg by its smell, the extreme chemical/cleaner fragrance should come right through the container. Given its countrywide commonplace (like mail-order Faberg Eggs – with scores of knockoff brands) you cant always find genuine Chem 4 among the imitations. We decided to review a golden-rod haired sample from Dank, which blatantly possessed the odor, the kind that fills up the house even when you try to double-bag it and hide it in the closet. The bud was meaty, but ground well and conjured more of the Chem smell, along with a lilt of strawberry, and maybe pistachio.

In general, most critics felt the power of the first hit nearly 5-10 minutes after puffing. A wowing rush ensued at that point, with various scores of mind-bending madness or confusion. Some of us where overwhelmed, disoriented, disorganized, and more. The brain recoiled into a quick mellow, as if shocked by pure electricity with a blurry return to focus. Our cerebral sensations continued to grow. The body, meanwhile, was permanent and heavy after only 20 minutes, abuzz and centered in the core.

After a half-hour, the initial craziness had died into a manageable high but warranted an encore. The second puff struck strongly but not quite as brilliant a supernova as the first. Still, one reviewer (at 160 lbs.) mentioned a sort of out-of-body sensation. Knees knocking and fingers flying, everyone was able to accomplish their day-to-day tasks. One reviewer wanted to relax more during the weekend, but said he was so focused on projects and outstanding debts or errands that he could do little to enjoy his day off, and could not sit still, despite feeling the need to.

The strain isnt a good all-day companion due to burnout. Focus is no problem; its the hand-eye coordination and syntax that suffer. Absolutely brilliant for music (and probably art) or any freestyle expression, Chem 4 may even offer the concentration needed for an early afternoon meeting. Two reviewers reported doing exceptionally better at the office (in moderate doses). Judgement and rationale were even heightened.

Be forewarned, however: multi-tasking is difficult, and directions or plans are bound to be lost somewhere in the footwork. Avoid multiple-stimuli environments like malls, school events, ball games or carnivals. The strain also had energizing effects at night. But if youre over the hump of exhaustion, youll welcome an expedited snooze.

Danks Chem Dawg 4 was hands-down, the best thing wed tried in four days, and not for the casual smoker. Perfect after a long day of work, expect to melt into statue-mode on the couch for a maximum duration 4-5 hours at maximum dosage–a perfect prelude to sleep. Munchies ranged from sweet to savory; we recommend yogurt-covered pretzels.

Profile: Indica

Testing: 21.03% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Blue Widow Hash Plant from Rocky Mountain Farmacy
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Blue Widow Hash Plant

Dispensary: Rocky Mountain Farmacy

When you visit South By Southwest in Austin, you expect to find the craziest new sounds, or at least the best version of the music you already know. The same is true of the CannaCritics when we frequent the occasional Denver Hash Bash (next one: Jan 29th, the official Cannapages 2 Year Birthday Party). Its five bucks to sample the citys hottest new exotic strains and award-winning traditional staples, all from Colorados finest dispensaries.

Regardless the free bowl-packing at the bud bar, we approached Rocky Mountain Farmacys booth – the only dispensary with much of a facade at the event. There, we met a dude named Doug, dressed as a Doctor, with a sexy nurse at his side. They had two samples–but we simply asked for the best, with the promise of review. He gladly packed us all one-hitters to sample to ourselves. Its Blue Widow Hash Plant, he explained, as a couple jaws dropped. Blueberry, White Widow, and Hash Plant.

Awestruck by the dernier cri, we all sat down–before sampling anything else in the house–and scribbled on a yellow piece of paper as we smoked for the first time that day, all of us fasting up until that very minute. Fast forward to mid-December, when our BWHP review finally tumbled out of a misplaced folder. We tied the notes together best we could from the chicken-scratch gibberish, some of which became too illegible to read.

From the Blueberry and White Widow parents, came a debonair (and real) Verbena Babylon blue hue. The thick bud was covered with a fiery mane of hair, finely trimmed with crystals still intact. One critic wrote that the bud looked like it had been rolled in the sugary rainbow lather sitting at the bottom of a Fruity pebble box. Its taste was that of toasty burnt marshmallow.

Everyone agreed upon the excellent first rush. First sensations included elevation and lip-buzzing, upper torso relief and general release through the face. One critic was numb and another started belching. The feeling we agreed upon in the end was a sinking throughout the head, as if gravity were pulling us through the floor.

At 30 minutes, the high had reached the extremities. Motivation was questionable at that point. Zoned out, most of us acquiesced to the scene. Our conversation went fairly limp. Linear thought was a joke. The high also encountered some awkwardness, with the inability to communicate, reported, as well as self-introspection bordering on paranoid vanity, but not without the charm of a foggy memory, post-embarrassment. This, quoted verbatim from our yellow sheet of paper.

For only 1.5 hits per reviewer, we were happy and satisfied. Most didnt go up to the bud bar until about an hour and fifteen minutes later, when we felt that the cerebral had crept away. The body could have resonated for another 25-60 minutes. In fact, with a slightly stronger dosage, even seasoned veterans would be momentarily paralyzed by one steam-roller hit, and affected for hours after two. Rolled, we would recommend of the joint for 2-hour experience.

Just like the craziest bands we saw in Austin (check out Solid Gold from Minneapolis) BWHP was weird and exotic, twisting several world flavors into a potent show-strain, prized for its novelty, and worth soliciting a stunning encore. When you need to impress with fascinating, midnight savoir faire, this is the selection.

Profile: Mostly Indica

Genetics: (Blueberry x White Widow) x Hash Plant

The high also encountered some awkwardness, with the inability to communicate, reported, as well as self-introspection bordering on paranoid vanity, but not without the charm of a foggy memory, post-embarrassment. Continue reading →

item.title: Querkle from Alternative Medicine on Capitol Hill
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Querkle

Dispensary: AMCH

Querkle can be as rare a find as the strains from which it was bred: Purple Urkle and Space Dude (the scientific name for a Space Queen male used in selective breeding). Combining the succulent grape indica with Queens exotic, cerebral lineage, Querkle is a complex, sweet strain whose flavors can vary from harvest to harvest.

Our latest sample came into the office quietly, but cracking the container was like popping open a pungent Cabernet. Its sandy light hairs and snow-white crystals covered a very enigmatic bud, aromatically-speaking. While critics agreed on sharp Romulan characteristics, they also noted fruit punch, sugar toast, and pound cake.

The first hit zapped our motivation immediately, and the task of writing actual reviews seemed impossible. Parts of the body rumbled slowly along, but the immediate take was very cerebral. The nerves rang and there was even tingling in the extremities. Each reviewer had measured difficulty even completing sentences for the first 20 minutes.

A mood-elevator and perfect chill out strain, Querkle should be handled carefully. Appointments were canceled, multi-tasking difficult, and there was no thinking outside the box. With cloudy heads, exercise was not possible, nor was reading. The created juices flowed, but not with the energy to manifest, perform, paint or build–any of it. In the end, those who enjoyed the strain most, chose to just sit back and enjoy as if taking in a dream. Watch a movie, one wrote, Or stumble down to the dock with fishing pole in hand.

Pain relief was at 60-70% with some sleepiness. Some Critics hailed the selections imperative for deep meditation, an introspective ride. Others found it easy to get lost in music, as they did way back in college, and lay down for an afternoon nap. The experience lasted 1.5-2 hours with red eyes the entire time…theres no faking this high. But if youve given into the instinct to isolate yourself from the general public, there shouldnt be any problem.

Querkle was exhilarating and somewhat debilitating. We enjoyed the Indica head-high, much different from the paranoia and craziness of too much Sativa. The strain must be used in moderation, especially to maintain a train of thought in day-to-day routine. A long duration and kind resolve means you can smoke this one throughout the day–but, of course, youll be completely worthless.

Profile: Indica

Testing: 17.03% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Banana Kush from Alternative Wellness Center
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Banana Kush

Dispensary: Alternative Wellness Center

A limited release, Banana Kush is like a seasonal foreign fruit that should be taken advantage of when found in good quality. But local growers have a roller-coaster of a time getting it right. Maybe its the strange fusion of OG Kush and Banana in high altitude, but you can barely keep the little buggers from turning into thin and burly buds with a sort of Yorkshire Terrier look. Although our specimen from Alternative Wellness Center came in as hairy and renegade as the lot, it was pleasantly thick, with a meaty substance not seen in competitors.

Naturally, its aroma was that of fresh plantains. Perhaps, a Banana Cream pie. Crystal cover was consistent and strong, but the bud was otherwise aromatically quiet. The grind released further tropical tones, fresh and cosmopolitan, yet we knew it was going to be a cougher.

The harsh first intake was followed by a weak build. It was mild. After 10 minutes, we savored and held a larger, second puff. Huge Difference. It was narcotic immediately, delivering a powerful blast of pain relief down the backs of the legs and tranquilizing all muscles within minutes.

Lethargy and heightened sleepiness followed. After a long day, the strain induced zone-out. Even for those who sampled the BK by day, syntax and focus didnt suffer so much as the ability to do things at normal pace. Patient but useless, speechless and endearing, it was well-suited for a walk in the woods but not necessarily one with conversation. Thirst was constant. By late-afternoon the strain began burning out. Potent enough to bring down midnight party-goers with one puff, BK is simply not something to pass around.

Artistic and humored, the high was convincing and heavy for two hours, with lingering effects. Reports included forgetfulness near the end, general spaciness evolving into spastic snoring and waking, blank staring into nothing, and a 2nd wind of energy, preluding deep slumber. A majority preferred the strain for listless Saturday evenings. Midnight snacking was entirely unavoidable.

Be warned: as one critic put it, the Banana Kush kind of turns you into the burnout/slow-philospher/weirdo that you see in the public service announcements. This is the kind of strain that burns pizzas in the oven when you sit down to open a dusty box of legos or a photo album, only to realize your house is on fire two hours later. Reserve it for a night cap or at least take the pizza out first.

Profile: Indica

Testing: 15.92% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Triple Sour Diesel from Trenchtown
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Triple Sour Diesel

Dispensary: Trenchtown

Trenchtown dispensary recently launched, doing its best to transport us highlanders to the low-lying wellspring of Jamaican culture. And with the Wailers kicking off their latest tour just days ago in our neck of the woods, it seemed only appropriate to see if the local med selection lived up to the moniker. Our critics agreed: although we can’t issue a Jamaican Order of Merit, we certainly concede these growers deserve it.

They proved it with their exquisitely aromatic Triple Sour Diesel. Its combination of Sour and NYC Diesels produced the expected Diesel-heavy notes with a slight citrus-chem of OG Kush thrown in. The bud was bright green with thick calyxes and velvety, rosewood-colored pistils. Passionately grown, the selection had been admirably pushed to the end of its cycle, well-flushed, and cured. It was even sticky.

The first hit was strong and massively cerebral, powerful and focused. Although energizing, there was no disguising its effects. The body became vibrant. It was a little tougher to socialize, recall names or phone numbers. But we were light on the feet. It was just enough for day-to-day functionality.

Although 1 puff wasnt the fun, impairing madness we were expecting, it was a true medical dose. Our limbs were numb; all but the worst of neck pains disappeared momentarily. Especially from the waist-down. We were satisfied with the overall problem-solving clarity and enjoyed a creative connection. The strain crept, but rapidly.

With a second dose came dumb mistakes, lost control, confusion and tremors. It was not for the faint-hearted. Emotional and psychedelic, we became terribly forgetful and made awful blunders. Great for crazy movies, you might even prefer grooved rifts from the stoniest of bands. We found ourselves listening to the Velvet Underground, Daft Punk and Ryksopp.

Over time, the narcotic body grew into a broad and lulling buzz. The whole TSD experience lasted a generous 3-4 hours, and was very unproductive by the end. A gamer or writers choice, it tended towards obsessive compulsive with prevalent munchies even by the first hour. Collectively, we were in the mood to listen and learn, just not to move.

Trenchtowns Triple Sour Diesel is a magnificent inaugural release. If their future generations continue at this quality, we cant wait to see them participate in upcoming cannabis cups.

Profile: Sativa

Testing: 21.54% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: G13 from Platte Valley Dispensary
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: G13

Dispensary: Platte Valley Dispensary

In tough times, the wise patient must make every gram count. Some do it with concentrates, and others, one-hitters and strict discipline. The key, however, is to find a strain that can deliver powerful punches in a small package. For us, it was recently G13 from Platte Valley Dispensary. These guys make a fairly wicked G13 Earwax too (x Bubba Kush — rave review forthcoming), but even their raw cannabis was dazzling enough to make just a few doses last all day long.

G13′s smell was startling from the moment we opened the jar; its deep grape was that of a blow pop sucker, mixed with a mysterious diesel fragrance. Sultry and curious; the aroma carried caramel musk and floral notes, with a subtle pinot noir sweetness. As for the bud, its careful cure had produced a golden crystal cover, adorning an otherwise purple foundation.

The first puff was a cross-eyed monster. It was so hard-hitting that a moment of shock ensued. Over the next 30 minutes, the rip-roaring experience featured an ever-growing cerebral energy, paired with a physical lethargy best nurtured in the soft velour of a La-Z-Boy recliner. Both body and mind were satisfied, as the medicine triggered points throughout the body, ultimately settling stressed nerves, while enhancing focus and momentary self-introspection into the sublime.

Nearly overwhelmed after two puffs, the head became existential and geocentric, curious but largely unsure. Mental processes slowed but did not come to a halt. Some small distractions could not be ignored, and were annoying in the obsessive-compulsive sense. But enhanced sensory perception kept everything new and novel, leaving us in excellent moods.

Even one dose of Platte Valleys selection may be too much for any sort of daytime functionality, especially manual labor. Aside from causing the fairly obvious relaxation, it had a slight tendency toward paranoia or at least buzzing couch-crash, rather than a typical indica sleep-aid. By 40-60 minutes, a zoned-out, hard-to-focus daze settled in, muddying input and output. Sloppiness manifested from weakened muscles and illusory depth perception.

For those of us who tested at night, sleep came, swiftly and undeniably. There was no avoiding slumber after the first few yawns; like Valerian, our motor skills faded and fizzled, as thoughts became blips on the radar. That said, dont expect the G13 to carry you through the day without midday nap and burnout. A mild dose 1 to 1.5 hours before bedtime should do the trick.

Profile: Indica

Testing: 19.27% Total Cannabinoids

See Full Results from Herbal Synergy

As for the bud, its careful cure had produced a golden crystal cover, adorning an otherwise purple foundation.

The first puff was a cross-eyed monster. It was so hard-hitting that a moment of shock ensued. Over the next 30 minutes, the rip-roaring experience featured an ever-growing cerebral energy, paired with a physical lethargy best nurtured in the soft velour of a La-Z-Boy recliner. Both body and mind were satisfied, as the medicine triggered points throughout the body, ultimately settling stressed nerves, while enhancing focus and momentary self-introspection into the sublime.

Nearly overwhelmed after two puffs, the head became existential and geocentric, curious but largely unsure. Mental processes slowed but did not come to a halt. Some small distractions could not be ignored, and were annoying in the obsessive-compulsive sense. But enhanced sensory perception kept everything new and novel, leaving us in excellent moods.

Even one dose of Platte Valleys selection may be too much for any sort of daytime functionality, especially manual labor. Aside from causing the fairly obvious relaxation, it had a slight tendency toward paranoia or at least buzzing couch-crash, rather than a typical indica sleep-aid. By 40-60 minutes, a zoned-out, hard-to-focus daze settled in, muddying input and output. Sloppiness manifested from weakened muscles and illusory depth perception.

For those of us who tested at night, sleep came, swiftly and undeniably. There was no avoiding slumber after the first few yawns; like Valerian, our motor skills faded and fizzled, as thoughts became blips on the radar. That said, dont expect the G13 to carry you through the day without midday nap and burnout. A mild dose 1 to 1.5 hours before bedtime should do the trick.

Profile: Indica

Testing: 19.27% Total Cannabinoids

item.title: Boston OG from Herbal Options
item.dc:creator: cannacritiques
item.content:encoded:
Strain: Boston OG

Dispensary: Herbal Options

The fine golden THC bulbs on Herbal Options Boston OG form a sea of sparkling sugar the color of a wheat beer. And with the sticky, lemony grind, we reviewers were ushered back to Chippewa Falls Irvine Park for a Leinies Shandy in July…or, to stick with the theme, a Sam Adams Summer Ale. Either way, its shades of citrus warmed us from an indica winter funk, with a fiery technicolor mane gracing a sharply-contrasted camouflage canvas.

Her first dose was impairing, especially after ten seconds. Hold that first hit. Boston knocked us out with hump-backed tremors and deep thought. Face and cheekbones relaxed, followed by jaw and neck. The high climbed steadily and strongly for at least 30-45 minutes. Blunders became a problem as focus and depth perception dawdled; it was both pleasurable and inspiring. All senses were enhanced, with a lingering, heightened pressure buzzing at the temples.

The laid-back relaxation removed stress and alleviated tense muscles. It was appropriate for a cold day indoors, but we philosophically yearned to go out or accomplish. Quite whimsically, critics were easily distracted but phenomenally in-tune…stopping the universe and all that jazz. Occasionally explosive (but unpredictable in that sense), it was a nice change of pace in this season of indicas to welcome the rip-roar of a heartwarming sativa.

Writers and socialites as we traditionally are, the strains hermitry bid us to retreat to our various errands alone, only to record mistakes and foggy heads. We did not accomplish that which we set out to. For many, lethargy developed into missed appointments. Goals went unreached. One whole to-do list was neglected entirely. By an hour, wed calmed down a bit, but not much.

Mostly disconnected, the experience was an unrelenting need to postpone and further push back all the things that still remained undone. The critics recommend Boston OG for a weekend afternoon spent gardening, or in preparation for the big game. One puff will probably do, even to pique the appetite.

Profile: Sativa

Testing: 24.74% Total Cannabinoids
